y) + geom_point() + opts(title=\"plot 3\")\r\ndev.off()\r\n\r\n\r\npdf(\"pdf_pdf.pdf\",  width=5,  height=5)\r\nggplot(df) + aes(x, y) + geom_point() + opts(title=\"plot Furthermore,  geom_bar does not work when both x and y are mapped to a data variable,  which is not exactly what you would expect from a bar geom.\n\nI think geom_bar with default stat=\"identity\",  and maybe position=\"dodge\" would deliver the most intuitive result.\n\nconsider this super simple example:\n\nyear <- 2001:2010;\ninflation<- runif(10);\nqplot(year,  inflation, geom=\"bar\"); { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ae892291f80064715" }, "updated_at" : "2011-12-02T16:53:48Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/95/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/95/comments", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/95", "comments" : 2, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/95/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/95", "created_at" : "2010-04-29T17:50:36Z", "number" : 95, "body" : "Let's consider this data\t\r\n\r\n\td <- data.frame(x=1:5,  y=c(runif(5),  runif(5)+5),  a=rep(c(\"foo\", \"bar\"),  each=5))\r\n\r\nThe scale for y should be free. Faceting along the horizontal makes it impossible since there should only be one y scale:\r\n\r\n\tggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x=x,  y=y)) + facet_grid(.~a,  scales=\"free_y\")\r\n\r\nThis makes sense but a warning would be welcome (\"Warning: The y scale cannot be free in this faceting configuration\")\r\n\r\nNow faceting along the vertical or switching the coordinates allows a free scale\r\n\r\n\tggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x=x,  y=y)) + facet_grid(a~.,  scales=\"free_y\")\r\n\tggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x=y,  y=x)) + facet_grid(.~a,  scales=\"free_x\")\r\n\r\nBut flipping the coordinate system does not,  while there are now two different axes for y\r\n\r\n\tggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x=x,  y=y)) + facet_grid(.~a,  scales=\"free_y\") + coord_flip()\r\n\r\nI would expect { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f80064925" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "comments" : 1, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2010-05-23T17:19:46Z", "number" : 103, "body" : "\r\nCurrently scale_area removes negative values:\r\n\r\n\tlibrary(\"ggplot2\")\r\n\r\n    d <- data.frame(x=runif(10),  y=runif(10),  z=rnorm(10)*10)\r\n\r\n    ggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x=x,  y=y,  size=z))\r\n    ggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x=x,  y=y,  size=z)) + scale_area()\r\n    # Warning messages:\r\n    # 1: In match.fun(get(\".transform\",  .))(values) : NaNs produced\r\n    # 2: Removed 6 rows containing missing values (geom_point). \r\n    # removes negative values\r\n\r\nThis is because it just computes the sqrt of the original values. The side effect of this,  by the way,  it that the visual difference between scale_size and scale_area depends on the range of the data which square root is being computed,  which seems wrong. Indeed,  the sqrt transformation here should happen on the radius of the points on the graph,  because it is that area we are concerned about (this is tricky,  I hope I am being clear).\r\n\r\nSo in fact,  scale_area should *map* the original values to the domain defined by the 'to' argument (e.g. 1 to 6) and then compute the sqrt of that. It would solve both problems at once. The patch below transforms the data to be all positive but I don't see a way to define the inverse transformation and therefore get correct legend labels.\r\n\r\n    diff --git a/R/trans-.r b/R/trans-.r\r\n    index f02e163..c180a2d 100644\r\n    --- a/R/trans-.r\r\n    +++ b/R/trans-.r\r\n    @@ -107, 6 +107, 7 @@ TransLog1p <- Trans$new(\"log1p\",  \"log1p\",  \"expm1\",  function(x) bquote(e^.(x+1)))\r\n     TransPow10 <- Trans$new(\"pow10\", function(x) 10^x,  \"log10\",  function(x) log10(x))\r\n     TransReverse <- Trans$new(\"reverse\",  function(x) -x,  function(x) -x,  function(x) bquote(.(-x)))\r\n     TransSqrt <- Trans$new(\"sqrt\",  \"sqrt\",  function(x) x^2,  function(x) x^2)\r\n    +TransArea <- Trans$new(\"area\",  function(x) sqrt(x+abs(min(x))),  function(x) x^2,  function(x) x^2)\r\n\r\n     TransDate <- Trans$new(\"date\",  \"as.numeric\",  \"to_date\")\r\n     TransDatetime <- Trans$new(\"datetime\",  \"as.numeric\",  \"to_time\")\r\n    diff --git a/R/trans-scales.r b/R/trans-scales.r\r\n    index c918896..0fa79e8 100644\r\n    --- a/R/trans-scales.r\r\n    +++ b/R/trans-scales.r\r\n    @@ -7, 7 +7, 7 @@ ScaleArea <- proto(\r\n       doc = FALSE, \r\n       new = function(.,  name=NULL,  limits=NULL,  breaks=NULL,  labels=NULL,  to = c(1,  6),  legend = TRUE) { \r\n         .super$new(.,  name = name,  limits = limits,  breaks = breaks,  \r\n    -       labels = labels,  trans=\"sqrt\",  to = to,  legend = legend)\r\n    +       labels = labels,  trans=\"area\",  to = to,  legend = legend)\r\n        }\r\n\r\n     )\r\n", "assignee" : null, "title" : "scale_area should work with negative values", "labels" : [ { "color" : "ededed", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/labels/scale", "name" : "scale" }, { "color" : "e02a2a", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/labels/bug", "name" : "bug" } ], "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/103/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/103/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-12-02T16:49:14Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/103", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/103", "updated_at" : "2011-12-02T16:49:14Z", "state" : "closed", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/103/labels{ /name }", "user" : { "type" : "User", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/orgs", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/followers", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/following", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/repos", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "229d40f963befad87276a08853d445f0", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/229d40f963befad87276a08853d445f0?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/events{ /privacy }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/received_events", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jiho/gists{ /gist_id }", "id" : 18445, "login" : "jiho" }, "id" : 204148, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f80064924" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "comments" : 3, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2010-05-29T14:09:55Z", "number" : 104, "body" : "squares of color for continuous scales are misleading: virtually everyone interprets them as the fact that ggplot is doing n discrete classes of data/color and using only those in the plot (and this is reinforced by the fact that the legend looks exactly like the discrete colour legend). In addition,  people are troubled by the fact that the min and max of the scale do not necessarily match the min and max in the data.\r\n\r\nI think that a gradient of color with numbers placed on the side (determined by the breaks argument) would be more appropriate. The gradient should go from the actual min to the actual max.\r\n\r\nI guess it is impossible to actually make a gradient in grid but 10 or so squares of color would readily give the illusion of a gradient. Anyhow,  as long as there are at least one additional square between two breaks,  people will understand that the scale is continuous.\r\n\r\nFor more complex scales where both size and colour are mapped to a continuous variable,  shapes could be superposed to the gradient. Such as in this example:\r\n\r\nhttp://dl.dropbox.com/u/1047321/ggplot/scale_gradient_ggplot2.pdf\r\nhttp://dl.dropbox.com/u/1047321/ggplot/scale_gradient_ggplot2.svg\r\n\r\nHere is a bit of code to test this:\r\n\r\n\tD = data.frame(x=runif(10),  y=runif(10),  z=runif(10))\r\n\r\n\tggplot(D) + geom_point(aes(x=x,  y=y,  colour=z,  size=z))", "assignee" : null, "title" : "Use an actual gradient { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f80064920" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "comments" : 3, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2010-06-21T17:28:28Z", "number" : 112, "body" : "Here is an example:\n\n\tlibrary(ggplot2)\n\td <- data.frame(x=runif(10),  y=rnorm(10))\n\tggplot(d) + geom_ribbon(aes(x=x,  ymin=y,  ymax=y+1))\n\tlast_plot() + coord_polar(theta=\"x\")\n\nWhich results in\n\n\tError in validDetails.polygon(x) : \n\t  'x' and 'y' and 'id' must all be same length\n\nAnd this is caused by commit a3c640bee846580c238f3d5c3ae2ba3ab70713bc\n\n\tAuthor: hadley <h.wickham@gmail.com>\n\tDate:   Fri Jun 11 10:25:37 2010 -0500\n \t   Manually incorporate patch for geom_smooth\n\nwhich introduced poly_ids,  which are not munched,  hence do not have the same length as x and y in coord_polar(). The following patch seems to fix it. I used ..ids.. as a new variable name to mimic what stats do when they produce new variables but maybe this not desirable.\n\n    diff --git a/R/geom-ribbon-.r b/R/geom-ribbon-.r\n    index c889746..9254cb0 100644\n    --- a/R/geom-ribbon-.r\n    +++ b/R/geom-ribbon-.r\n    @@ -16, 8 +16, 8 @@ GeomRibbon <- proto(Geom,  { \n        # has distinct polygon numbers for sequences of non-NA values and NA\n        # for NA values in the original data.  Example: c(NA,  2,  2,  2,  NA,  NA, \n        # 4,  4,  4,  NA)\n    -    poly_ids <- cumsum(!complete.cases(data[ required_aes ])) + 1\n    -    poly_ids[ !complete.cases(data[ required_aes ]) ] <- NA\n    +    data$..ids.. <- cumsum(!complete.cases(data[ required_aes ])) + 1\n    +    data$..ids..[ !complete.cases(data[ required_aes ]) ] <- NA\n \n        tb <- with(data, \n          coordinates$munch(data.frame(x=c(x,  rev(x)),  y=c(ymax,  rev(ymin))),  scales)\n    @@ -25, 12 +25, 12 @@ GeomRibbon <- proto(Geom,  { \n \n        with(data,  ggname(.$my_name(),  gTree(children=gList(\n          ggname(\"fill\",  polygonGrob(\n    -        tb$x,  tb$y,  id=c(poly_ids,  rev(poly_ids)), \n    +        tb$x,  tb$y,  tb$..ids.., \n            default.units=\"native\", \n            gp=gpar(fill=alpha(fill,  alpha),  col=NA) \n          )), \n          ggname(\"outline\",  polygonGrob(\n    - { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f80064908" }, "updated_at" : "2011-12-02T16:39:19Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/139/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/139/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-12-02T16:39:19Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/139", "comments" : 1, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/139/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/139", "created_at" : "2010-09-10T21:16:13Z", "number" : 139, "body" : "As pointed out:\nhttp://groups.google.com/group/ggplot2/browse_thread/thread/d6fe322090aae4bd/0201c67637ab1e9f\nand\nhttp://groups.google.com/group/ggplot2/browse_thread/thread/5e4cb9d6d3b36b2f/31f69c8fc32f2558\n<pre>\nqplot(cut,  data=diamonds,  geom=\"bar\", fill=color)\n</pre>\nBars are stacked from D/bottom to J/top,  but the legend is stacked from J/bottom to D/top. \n\nAs pointed out in the group,  this appears to only affect stacked barplots and can be fixed by setting the breaks manually. I am suggesting that the default legend order for a stacked barplot be a reversal of the stack order. \n\n<pre>\nqplot(cut,  data=diamonds,  geom=\"bar\", fill=color) + \nscale_fill_discrete(breaks = rev(levels(diamonds$color)))  \n</pre>", "title" : "Default legend order for stacked barplot backwards", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/repos", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "f644cd07dcaf5fe63f8c08bd7df02a39", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/events{ /privacy }", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/f644cd07dcaf5fe63f8c08bd7df02a39?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "login" : "bhive01", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/received_events", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/orgs", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/followers", "id" : 394973, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bhive01/following" }, "id" : 311384, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648fc" }, "updated_at" : "2011-12-02T16:35:36Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/153/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/153/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-12-02T16:35:36Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/153", "comments" : 2, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/153/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/153", "created_at" : "2010-12-17T20:55:24Z", "number" : 153, "body" : "# Summary:\r\n\r\ncoord_equal() does not make the coordinate systems have an equal aspect ratio when using facet_wrap() in the cases where it is the horizontal axis which must be extended to make the coordinates equal.  coord_equal() will affect the coordinate systems for vertically stretched axes when using facet_wrap(),  and in all case when using facet_grid().\r\n\r\n# Reproducible code:\r\n\r\n    p_horiz_stretch <- ggplot(mtcars) +\r\n    geom_point(aes(x=5*hp,  y=disp)) +\r\n    geom_abline() +\r\n    coord_equal()\r\n    \r\n    p_vert_stretch <- ggplot(mtcars) +\r\n    geom_point(aes(x=hp,  y=5*disp)) +\r\n    geom_abline() +\r\n    coord_equal()\r\n    \r\n    p_horiz_stretch\r\n    p_horiz_stretch + facet_grid(am~.)\r\n    p_horiz_stretch + facet_grid(~am)\r\n    p_horiz_stretch + facet_wrap(~am)\r\n    \r\n    p_vert_stretch\r\n    p_vert_stretch + facet_grid(am~.)\r\n    p_vert_stretch + facet_grid(~am)\r\n    p_vert_stretch + facet_wrap(~am)\r\n\r\n# Expected results:\r\n\r\nfacet_grid(~am) and facet_wrap(~am) should give the same figure (at least with respect to coordinate aspect ratios).\r\n\r\n# Actual results:\r\n\r\nFor p_horiz_stretch,  facet_grid(~am) maintains the aspect ratio while facet_wrap(~am) does not. It appears,  rather,  to make the plot area square,  not make the aspect ratio 1.  That is,  it has an effect (plot is different than if coord_equal() was left out completely),  but not the right one. For p_vert_stretch,  both maintain the aspect ratio.\r\n\r\n# Discussion:\r\n\r\np_horiz_stretch is a plot (using mtcars) where the x-axis has to be stretched (or the y-axis has to be contracted,  depending on how you look at it) to make the coordinate systems equal.  In addition to the points,  a line with slope 1 is also drawn to make it easier to identify if the coordinates are in fact equal. Faceting,  via facet_grid(),  in either direction,  maintains the appropriate ratio. However,  wrapping,  which for the two values of am should be the same as the immediately previous call with facet_grid,  does not preserve the aspect ratio.  By way of comparison,  p_vert_stretch is a plot where the y-axis has be stretched (x-axis has to be contracted) which behaves as expected in all four scenarios.\r\n\r\n# Session Info:\r\n\r\n    R version 2.12.1 (2010-12-16)\r\n    Platform: i386-pc-mingw32/i386 (32-bit)\r\n    \r\n    locale:\r\n    [ 1 ] LC_COLLATE=English_United States.1252  LC_CTYPE=English_United States.1252   \r\n    [ 3    graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n    \r\n    other attached packages:\r\n    [ 1 ] ggplot2_0.8.8 proto_0.3-8   reshape_0.8.3 plyr_1.2.1 ", "title" : "coord_equal() has { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648f9" }, "updated_at" : "2011-01-12T18:52:10Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/157/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/157/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-01-12T18:52:10Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/157", "comments" : 3, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/157/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/157", "created_at" : "2011-01-11T17:04:02Z", "number" : 157, "body" : "# Summary:\r\n\r\nWhen given a set of data with only a single unique x value and a position request,  an error is thrown and no graphic is created.\r\n\r\n# Reproducible code:\r\n\r\n    df1 <- data.frame(x=1,  y=1)\r\n    ggplot(df1,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + geom_point(position=\"dodge\")\r\n    ggplot(df1,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + geom_point(position=\"stack\")\r\n\r\n# Expected results:\r\n\r\nA graph with a single point.\r\n\r\n# Actual results:\r\n\r\n    > df1 <- data.frame(x=1,  y=1)\r\n    > ggplot(df1,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + geom_point(position=\"dodge\")\r\n    Error in if (any(diff(intervals) < -1e-06)) {  : \r\n      missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed\r\n    > ggplot(df1,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + geom_point(position=\"stack\")\r\n    Error in if (any(diff(intervals) < -1e-06)) {  : \r\n      missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed\r\n\r\n# Problem:\r\n\r\nIn collide in position-collide.r,  the intervals for the x values are scaled (by base::scale) in order for the check on the threshold difference between edges to be tested on the proper scale (differences on the order of 1e-6 for measures on the order of 1).  However,  if there is only one unique x value,  the standard deviation is 0 and the scaled values are NaN which lead to NA's when testing.\r\n\r\n# Proposed patch:\r\n\r\n    @@ -34, 8 +34, 8 @@ collide <- function(data,  width = NULL,  name,  strategy,  check.width = TRUE) { \r\n     \r\n       # Check for overlap\r\n       intervals <- as.numeric(t(unique(data[ c(\"xmin\",  \"xmax\") ])))\r\n    -  intervals <- scale(intervals[ !is.na(intervals) ])\r\n    -  if (any(diff(intervals) < -1e-6)) { \r\n    +  intervals <- intervals[ !is.na(intervals) ]\r\n    +  if (length(unique(intervals))>1 & any(diff(scale(intervals)) < -1e-6)) { \r\n         warning(name,  \" requires non-overlapping x intervals\",  call. = FALSE)\r\n         # This is where the algorithm from [ L. Wilkinson. Dot plots. \r\n         # The American Statistician,  1999. ] should be used\r\n\r\nThis checks the number of unique values before the computation of the scaled intervals and testing of their differences.\r\n\r\n# Session Info:\r\n\r\n    R version 2.12.1 (2010-12-16)\r\n    Platform: i386-pc-mingw32/i386 (32-bit)\r\n    \r\n    locale:\r\n    [ 1 ] LC_COLLATE=English_United States.1252 reshape_0.8.3 plyr_1.4     \r\n    \r\n    loaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n    [ 1 ] digest_0.4.2 tools_2.12.1\r\n", "title" : "position adjustment gives error when only one unique x value", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/repos", "subscriptions_url" : { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648f8" }, "updated_at" : "2011-01-18T10:01:23Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/158/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/158/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-01-13T02:05:57Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/158", "comments" : 2, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/158/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/158", "created_at" : "2011-01-12T08:37:39Z", "number" : 158, "body" : "Rather than having a just \"colour\" argument to plotmatrix() add ... and pass it to geom_point,  so that any property (not just colour) can be set. E.g.\r\n\r\n    plotmatrix(d,  mapping=aes(colour=someVariable),  size=1,  alpha=0.7)\r\n\r\nChanging the code to this should be enough:\r\n\r\n\tplotmatrix = function (data,  mapping = aes(),  ...) \r\n\t{ \r\n\t    grid <- expand.grid(x = 1:ncol(data),  y = 1:ncol(data))\r\n\t    grid <- subset(grid,  x != y)\r\n\t    all <- do.call(\"rbind\",  lapply(1:nrow(grid),  function(i) { \r\n\t        xcol <- grid[ i,  \"x\" ]\r\n\t        ycol <- grid[ i,  \"y\" ]\r\n\t        data.frame(xvar = names(data)[ ycol ],  yvar = names(data)[ xcol ],  \r\n\t            x = data[ ,  xcol ],  y = data[ ,  ycol ],  data)\r\n\t     }))\r\n\t    all$xvar <- factor(all$xvar,  levels = names(data))\r\n\t    all$yvar <- factor(all$yvar,  levels = names(data))\r\n\t    densities <- do.call(\"rbind\",  lapply(1:ncol(data),  function(i) { \r\n\t        data.frame(xvar = names(data)[ i ],  yvar = names(data)[ i ],  \r\n\t            x = data[ ,  i ])\r\n\t     }))\r\n\t    mapping <- defaults(mapping,  aes_string(x = \"x\",  y = \"y\"))\r\n\t    class(mapping) <- \"uneval\"\r\n\t    ggplot(all,  mapping) + facet_grid(xvar ~ yvar,  scales = \"free\") + \r\n\t        geom_point(na.rm = TRUE,  ...) + { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648eb" }, "updated_at" : "2011-04-12T17:29:42Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/172/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/172/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-04-12T17:29:42Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/172", "comments" : 2, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/172/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/172", "created_at" : "2011-04-11T16:46:01Z", "number" : 172, "body" : "The current implementation of the `interp` function can be made simpler and a little quicker.  It currently looks like this:\r\n\r\n    interp <- function (start,  end,  n) \r\n    { \r\n        if (n == 1) \r\n            return(start)\r\n        start + seq(0,  1,  length = n) * (end - start)\r\n     }\r\n\r\nA better implementation might be\r\n\r\n    interp <- function (start,  end,  n) \r\n    { \r\n        seq.int(start,  end,  length.out = n)    \r\n     }\r\n\r\nThe advantages are that \r\n1) the code is cleaner and shorter\r\n2) `seq.int` is faster than `seq`\r\n\r\nNote that the answer can differ by small values due to floating point errors,  e.g., \r\n\r\n    start <- 1.3\r\n    end <- 2.9\r\n    n <- 7\r\n    i <- interp(start,  end,  n)\r\n    j <- seq.int(start,  end,  length.out = n)\r\n    abs(i - j)\r\n\r\nNote that the special case handling for `n = 1` isn't required,  since \r\n\r\n    identical(start,  seq.int(start,  end,  length.out = 1)) #TRUE", "title" : "interp function can be simplified", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [ { "color" : "ededed", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/labels/coord", "name" : "coord" }, { "color" : "32c243", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/labels/feature", "name" : "feature" } ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/repos", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "85c1a01d3843ecaa30abd003b65811a8", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/events{ /privacy }", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/85c1a01d3843ecaa30abd003b65811a8?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "login" : "richierocks", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/received_events", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/orgs", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/followers", "id" : 197589, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/richierocks/following" }, "id" : 755018, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648de" }, "updated_at" : "2011-05-23T13:07:10Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/186/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/186/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-05-23T13:07:10Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/186", "comments" : 1, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/186/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/186", "created_at" : "2011-05-23T06:35:39Z", "number" : 186, "body" : "When ggplot2 is loaded,  it loads reshape,  which masks some functions from reshape2 and plyr. This has caused some problems for me,  in cases where the function definition has changed between the two versions. For example,  with `melt`:\r\n\r\n    > library(reshape2)\r\n    > melt(smiths,  id.vars = \"subject\",  measure.vars=c(\"time\", \"age\"),  variable.name=\"feature\")\r\n         subject feature value\r\n    1 John Smith    time     1\r\n    2 Mary Smith    time     1\r\n    3 John Smith     age    33\r\n    4 Mary Smith     age    NA\r\n\r\nThat worked OK. Now load ggplot2,  which masks some functions.\r\n\r\n    > library(ggplot2)\r\n    Loading required package: reshape\r\n    Loading required package: plyr\r\n    \r\n    Attaching package: 'reshape'\r\n    \r\n    The following object(s) are masked from 'package:plyr':\r\n    \r\n        rename,  round_any\r\n    \r\n    The following object(s) are masked from 'package:reshape2':\r\n    \r\n        colsplit,  melt,  recast\r\n    \r\n    Loading required package: grid\r\n    Loading required package: proto\r\n\r\nTry again (this calls the version of melt from reshape).\r\n\r\n    > melt(smiths,  id.vars = \"subject\",  measure.vars=c(\"time\", \"age\"),  variable.name=\"feature\")\r\n         subject variable value\r\n    1 John Smith     time     1\r\n    2 Mary Smith     time     1\r\n    3 John Smith      age    33\r\n    4 Mary Smith      age    NA\r\n\r\nNotice that the column that was called \"feature\" is now called \"variable\",  because the relevant argument in reshape2 is `variable.name`,  but in reshape it is `variable_name`.\r\n\r\n", "title" : "Loading ggplot2 loads reshape,  which masks functions from reshape2 and plyr", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [ When facet_wrap() or facet_grid() are used,  if any one facet has no breaks in range,  an error is returned and none are plotted.\r\n\r\n```R\r\ndat <- data.frame(x = rep(1:4,  4),  y = rep(1:4,  each = 4), \r\n  z = 1:16,  g = factor(rep(1:2,  each = 8)))\r\n\r\n## fails because break is out of range\r\nggplot(dat) +\r\n  stat_contour(aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = z),  breaks = 20)\r\n\r\n## fails because all breaks are out of range for one facet\r\nggplot(dat) +\r\n  facet_wrap(~g) +\r\n  stat_contour(aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = z),  breaks = 12)\r\n```\r\nstat_contour() seems to return an error because when no breaks are in range,  contour_df is not properly converted to a data frame.  One option would be to create the plot,  but not add lines by simply setting contour_df to an empty data frame.  The code below is a possible addition to stat_contour to do this.\r\n\r\n```R\r\n   # section added to avoid errors when breaks are out of range\r\n    if (all(breaks < min(data$z) | breaks > max(data$z))) { \r\n      warning(\"All specified breaks are outside the range of z\r\n      no contours will be drawn in this plot/facet\")\r\n      contour_df <- data.frame(level = NULL,  x = NULL,  y= NULL, \r\n        piece = NULL,  group = NULL)\r\n      return(contour_df)\r\n     }\r\n```", "title" : "breaks in stat_contour", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [ { "color" : "ededed", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/labels/stat", "name" : "stat" }, { "color" : "e02a2a", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/labels/bug", "name" : "bug" } ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/repos", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "c8c0c7e99a79ec1236666dcaa040046f", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/events{ /privacy }", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c8c0c7e99a79ec1236666dcaa040046f?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "login" : "JWiley", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/received_events", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/orgs", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/followers", "id" : 322716, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/JWiley/following" }, "id" : 1119430, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648c5" }, "updated_at" : "2011-12-15T13:15:16Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/213/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/213/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-12-10T13:26:16Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/213", "comments" : 3, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/213/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/213", "created_at" : "2011-08-02T18:27:43Z", "number" : 213, "body" : "# Description\r\n\r\nIn the develop branch,  when calling summary on a ggplot object,  it exits with an error when printing the faceting information\r\n\r\n# Reproducible code\r\n\r\n```r\r\nsummary(ggplot())\r\n```\r\n\r\n# Actual output\r\n\r\n```\r\n> summary(ggplot())\r\ndata: [ 0x0 ]\r\nfaceting: Error in summary.ggplot(ggplot()) : attempt to apply non-function\r\n```\r\n\r\n# Expected output\r\n\r\nIn version 0.8.9,  the output is\r\n\r\n```\r\n> summary(ggplot())\r\ndata: [ 0x0 ]\r\nfaceting: facet_grid(. ~ .,  FALSE)\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis is not necessarily what it should be,  but at least it shouldn't throw an error.\r\n\r\n# Diagnosis\r\n\r\nIn `summary.ggplot`,  (https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/blob/develop/R/summary.r#L35),  there is the call `object$facet$pprint()`.  git blame shows this line is from the initial import of ggplot to git.  Since the results of a facet are no longer a `proto` object,  but a list of class \"facet\",  there is no `pprint` function to call.  A `print.facet` (and maybe a `summary.facet`?) function is needed to print out a summary appropriate for this use.\r\n\r\n# sessionInfo\r\n\r\n```\r\n> sessionInfo()\r\nR version 2.13.1 { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648c4" }, "updated_at" : "2011-12-20T00:58:29Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/214/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/214/comments", "closed_at" : "2011-12-20T00:58:29Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/214", "comments" : 7, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/214/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/214", "created_at" : "2011-08-02T22:33:42Z", "number" : 214, "body" : "# Description\r\n\r\nThe displayed plot can vary depending on the setting of the global option `stringsAsFactors`.\r\n\r\n# Reproducible code\r\n\r\n```r\r\n(sAF <- getOption(\"stringsAsFactors\"))\r\n\r\noptions(stringsAsFactors = FALSE)\r\ndat1 <- data.frame(x=letters[ 5:1 ], y=runif(5))\r\nggplot(dat1, aes(x=as.character(x), y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n\r\noptions(stringsAsFactors = TRUE)\r\ndat1 <- data.frame(x=letters[ 5:1 ], y=runif(5))\r\nggplot(dat1, aes(x=as.character(x), y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n\r\noptions(stringsAsFactors = sAF)\r\n```\r\n\r\n# Expected results\r\n\r\nThe two graphs should be identical.  The `as.character` in the aesthetic should remove any issues whether `x` in `dat1` is a character or factor.\r\n\r\n# Actual results\r\n\r\nThe former has the x axis ordered e -> a,  the latter a -> e.\r\n\r\n# thattat test code\r\n\r\n```r\r\ntest_that(\"stringsAsFactors\",  { \r\n\r\n    sAF <- getOption(\"stringsAsFactors\")\r\n    dat.character <- data.frame(x=letters[ 5:1 ],  y=1:5,  stringsAsFactors=FALSE)\r\n    dat.factor <- data.frame(x=letters[ 5:1 ],  y=1:5,  stringsAsFactors=TRUE)\r\n    \r\n    options(stringsAsFactors = TRUE)\r\n    p.character.TRUE <- ggplot(dat.character,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n    build.character.TRUE <- ggplot_build(p.character.TRUE)\r\n    p.factor.TRUE <- ggplot(dat.factor,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n    build.factor.TRUE <- ggplot_build(p.factor.TRUE)\r\n\r\n    options(stringsAsFactors = FALSE)\r\n    p.character.FALSE <- ggplot(dat.character,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n    build.character.FALSE <- ggplot_build(p.character.FALSE)\r\n    p.factor.FALSE <- ggplot(dat.factor,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n    build.factor.FALSE <- ggplot_build(p.factor.FALSE)\r\n\r\n    options(stringsAsFactors = sAF)\r\n    \r\n    expect_that(p.factor.FALSE,  equals(p.factor.FALSE))\r\n    expect_that(build.factor.FALSE,  equals(build.factor.TRUE))\r\n    expect_that(p.character.FALSE,  equals(p.character.FALSE))\r\n    expect_that(build.character.FALSE,  equals(build.character.TRUE))\r\n })\r\n```\r\n\r\nRunning this on the current development branch gives:\r\n\r\n```\r\nError: Test failure in 'stringsAsFactors'\r\nbuild.character.FALSE not equal to build.character.TRUE\r\nComponent 1: Component 1: Component 1: Mean relative difference: 1\r\nComponent 2: Component 5: Component 1: Component 4: 4 string mismatches\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe first component mismatch is in the x component of the data element.  One set is 1:5,  the other is 5:1.  The second component mismatch is in the x axis labels (\"a\" -> \"e\" versus \"e\" -> \"a\").\r\n\r\n# Discussion\r\n\r\nThe problem happens in the build process (ggplot_build) only when one of the aesthetics is a character (not a factor).  I believe that this is probably due to a `data.frame` call which has the character vector which is converted to a factor (ordered) or not (stays unordered) based on the global option.  Wherever this internal code is,  it should enforce a particular choice.  Traditionally,  this choice has been `stringsAsFactors=TRUE`; ggplot has used the generic ordering that is gotten from a simple conversion of a character vector to a factor to determine the displayed order.\r\n\r\nNote that the `test_that` code checks both character and factor cases and checks at the ggplot specification and built ggplot level.  One one of these gives an error.  The others guard against regressions.\r\n\r\n# sessionInfo\r\n\r\n```\r\n> sessionInfo()\r\nR version 2.13.1 (2011-07-08)\r\nPlatform: x86_64-pc-mingw32/x64 (64-bit)\r\n\r\nlocale:\r\n[ 1 ] LC_COLLATE=English_United States.1252 \r\n[ 2 ] LC_CTYPE=English_United States.1252   \r\n[ 3 ] LC_MONETARY=English_United States.1252\r\n[ 4 ] LC_NUMERIC=C                          \r\n[ 5 ] LC_TIME=English_United States.1252    \r\n\r\nattached base packages:\r\n[ 1 ] grid      stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods  \r\n[ 8 ] base     \r\n\r\nother attached packages:\r\n [ 1 ] testthat_0.5  ggplot2_0.9.0 memoise_0.1   scales_0.1.0  reshape2_1.1 \r\n [ 6 ] plyr_1.6      proto_0.3-9.2 roxygen2_2.0  digest_0.5.0  devtools_0.4 \r\n\r\nloaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n [ 1 ] brew_1.0-6         codetools_0.2-8    colorspace_1.1-0   dichromat_1.2-3   \r\n [ 5 ] evaluate_0.3       munsell_0.2        mutatr_0.1.2       RColorBrewer_1.0-5\r\n [ 9 ] RCurl_1.6-6.1      stringr_0.5        tools_2.13.1      \r\n```\r\n\r\n", "title" : "Plot sensitivie to stringsAsFactors option", "milestone" : { "due_on" : null, "state" : "closed", "labels_url" : { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ce892291f800648c3" }, "updated_at" : "2012-04-05T17:05:48Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/215/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/215/comments", "closed_at" : "2012-04-05T17:05:48Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/215", "comments" : 1, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/215/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/215", "created_at" : "2011-08-04T12:37:58Z", "number" : 215, "body" : "```R\r\nggplot()+geom_boxplot(aes(x='BoxPlot Bug', y=c(1, 2)), coef=0.0)+ylim(c(-5, 5))\r\nWarning messages:\r\n1: In min(x) : no non-missing arguments to min; returning Inf\r\n2: In max(x) : no non-missing arguments to max; returning -Inf\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe resulting plot contains two vertical lines for the hinges.\r\n\r\nOne possible fix is to adjust the call to range within the calculate method of StatBoxplot:\r\n\r\n```R\r\n      if (any(outliers)) stats[ c(1,  5) ] <- range(c(y[ !outliers ], stats[ 2 ], stats[ 4 ]),  na.rm=TRUE)\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe whole function:\r\n\r\n```R\r\n  calculate <- function(.,  data,  scales,  width=NULL,  na.rm = FALSE,  coef = 1.5,  ...) { \r\n    with(data,  { \r\n      qs <- c(0,  0.25,  0.5,  0.75,  1)\r\n      if (length(unique(weight)) != 1) { \r\n        try_require(\"quantreg\")\r\n        stats <- as.numeric(coef(rq(y ~ 1,  weights = weight,  tau=qs)))\r\n       } else { \r\n        stats <- as.numeric(quantile(y,  qs))\r\n       }\r\n      names(stats) <- c(\"ymin\",  \"lower\",  \"middle\",  \"upper\",  \"ymax\")\r\n\r\n      iqr <- diff(stats[ c(2,  4) ])\r\n\r\n      outliers <- y < (stats[ 2 ] - coef * iqr) | y > (stats[ 4 ] + coef * iqr)\r\n      if (any(outliers)) stats[ c(1,  5) ] <- range(c(y[ !outliers ], stats[ 2 ], stats[ 4 ]),  na.rm=TRUE)\r\n\r\n      if (length(unique(x)) > 1) width <- diff(range(x)) * 0.9\r\n\r\n      df <- as.data.frame(as.list(stats))\r\n      df$outliers <- I(list(y[ outliers ]))\r\n\r\n      transform(df, \r\n        x = if (is.factor(x)) x[ 1 ] else mean(range(x)), \r\n        width = width\r\n      )\r\n     })\r\n   }\r\n```\r\n\r\nSee also: Issue #108: [ Incorrect hinge calculation in stat_boxplot for v. small datasets ](https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/108)\r\n\r\n", "title" : "stat_boxplot generates infinities for small datasets", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [ { "color" : "e02a2a", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/labels/bug", "name" : "bug" } ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/repos", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "af5cc2aab1da8e22c847d1113e7410ca", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/events{ /privacy }", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/af5cc2aab1da8e22c847d1113e7410ca?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "login" : "aschweig", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/received_events", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/orgs", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/followers", "id" : 958887, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/aschweig/following" }, "id" : 1344012, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f800648b6" }, "comments" : 1, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2011-08-22T12:25:16Z", "number" : 231, "body" : "If all the values in the input `x` are the same (i.e. if `all(diff(x) == 0))` then percent returns `NaN`.  For example\r\n\r\n    percent(100)             #\"NaN%\"\r\n    percent(rep.int(1,  3))   #\"NaN%\" \"NaN%\" \"NaN%\"\r\n\r\nThe problem seems to be that in this case `precision(x)` returns 0,  which then causes `round_any` to calculate `Inf * 0`.\r\n\r\nA possible fix is to change the definition of percent to be\r\n\r\n    percent <- function(x) \r\n    { \r\n      x <- round_any(x,  max(1,  precision(x))/10)\r\n      paste(comma(x * 100),  \"%\",  sep = \"\")\r\n     }\r\n", "assignee" : null, "title" : "percent returns NaN when all inputs take the same value", "labels" : [  ], { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f800648ac" }, "comments" : 0, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2011-09-28T21:50:29Z", "number" : 242, "body" : "It seems geom=bar does not allow for NA values in the data\r\n\r\n```R\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\ndf_withNA<-data.frame(value=c(runif(19), NA),  factor=sample(c(\"A\", \"B\"),  size=20,  replace=TRUE))\r\ndf_NoNA<-data.frame(value=runif(20),  factor=sample(c(\"A\", \"B\"),  size=20,  replace=TRUE))\r\n\r\nqplot(x=factor,  y=value,  data=df_NoNA,  geom=\"bar\",  stat=\"identity\")\r\nqplot(x=factor,  y=value,  data=df_withNA,  geom=\"bar\",  stat=\"identity\")\r\n```\r\n\r\none then gets the error:\r\n```\r\nErreur dans if (!is.null(data$ymin) && !all(data$ymin == 0)) warning(\"Stacking not well defined when ymin != 0\",   :\r\n valeur manquante là où TRUE / FALSE est requis\r\n```\r\n\r\nPROPOSED SOLUTION\r\nThis is most likely to be due to the fact that within the calls,   pmin() is used without the na.rm=TRUE argument.\r\n\r\nIndeed,  if one changes in geom-bar.r\r\n```ymin = pmin(y,  0),  ymax = pmax(y,  0), ```\r\n\r\nto\r\n```ymin = pmin(y,  0,  na.rm=TRUE),  ymax = pmax(y,  0,  na.rm=TRUE)```\r\n\r\nthe bug does not appear anymore. { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f800648a5" }, "comments" : 1, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2011-10-31T16:26:46Z", "number" : 251, "body" : "With the development branch,  I've had problems adding scale_y_continuous to a saved ggplot object. I had a hard time figuring out how to consistently replicate the bug,  because it depends whether the object has already been printed.  To replicate,  the commands below have to be run in the order given.\r\n\r\n```\r\n# Random data\r\ndat <- data.frame(x=rnorm(20),  y=rnorm(20))\r\n\r\n# Make plot object\r\nps <- ggplot(dat,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n\r\n# Print it\r\nps\r\n\r\n# Adding scale_y_continuous has no effect\r\nps + scale_y_continuous(breaks=c(.1, .2, .5)) \r\n```\r\n\r\nBut if you skip the printing of ps by itself,  adding the scale works.\r\n\r\n```\r\nps <- ggplot(dat,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n\r\n# Adding scale_y_continuous works this time\r\nps + scale_y_continuous(breaks=c(.1, .2, .5)) \r\n```\r\n\r\nIf,  instead of printing \"ps\" by itself,  you add a scale with no parameters set,  it doesn't mess thing up for later use with a scale.\r\n\r\n```\r\nps <- ggplot(dat,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point()\r\n\r\n# Add a scale with no options set\r\nps + scale_y_continuous() \r\n\r\n# Adding scale_y_continuous works\r\nps + scale_y_continuous(breaks=c(.1, .2, .5)) \r\n```\r\n\r\n", { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f800648a1" }, "comments" : 1, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2011-11-01T21:47:57Z", "number" : 255, "body" : "I'm not totally sure if this is a bug,  or if it's expected behavior.\r\n\r\nSuppose you define the aes mapping ymin=y+ci,  and then add another geom that uses a second data frame which doesn't have a \"ci\" column. Then it fails,  even if ymin is not used by that geom. This is shown in the example here:\r\n\r\n```\r\n# Primary data source\r\nd1 <- data.frame(x=1:10,  y=rnorm(10),  ci=(1:10)/10)\r\n\r\n# Add some secondary data\r\nd2 <- data.frame(x=2*(1:5),  y=rnorm(5))\r\n\r\n# This fails\r\nggplot(d1,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  ymin=y-ci,  ymax=y+ci)) + \r\n    geom_ribbon(fill=\"grey80\") +\r\n    geom_line() +\r\n    geom_line(data=d2,  colour=\"red\")\r\n\r\n# Error in eval(expr,  envir,  enclos) : object 'ci' not found\r\n```\r\n\r\nA workaround is to move the ymin and ymax inside of geom_ribbon:\r\n\r\n```\r\nggplot(d1,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + \r\n    geom_ribbon(aes(ymin=y-ci,  ymax=y+ci),  fill=\"grey80\") +\r\n    geom_line() +\r\n    geom_line(data=d2,  colour=\"red\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis isn't that difficult in this example,  but in practice it can be kind of tedious and require lots of redundant code. I've made some complicated graphs with a lot of text annotations and I've to specify these mappings over and over.\r\n", "assignee" : null, "title" : "vars in aes() which aren't present in secondary data frame cause problems", "labels" : [  ], "closed_at" : "2011-11-02T09:44:40Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/255", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/255/events", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/255", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/255/comments", "updated_at" : "2011-11-02T09:44:40Z", "state" : "closed", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/255/labels{ /name }", "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "id" : 86978, "login" : "wch" }, "id" : 2115559, "pull_request" : { "patch_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8ae892291f800646ff" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "updated_at" : "2012-07-26T15:44:40Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/257", "comments" : 1, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/257/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/257/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/257/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/257", "created_at" : "2011-11-04T04:04:40Z", "number" : 257, "body" : "This is with the development branch. I just tried making a stacked area graph with a log y scale,  and found that the plotted values were way,  way off. It was only after I tried it that I realized that stacking with a log scale either makes no sense,  or will be very misleading -- though I personally can't rule out the possibility that _some_ stacked log-scale graph could make sense.\r\n\r\nAt any rate,  it seems to me that ggplot should (A) give a warning or error when you attempt this,  and (B) not make a graph with incorrect values.\r\n\r\nIn this example,  I have data that grows exponentially. The largest summed value is 4e+10. It shows fine with a linear-scale. When I add the log scale,  the growth is a straight line,  which is correct,  but the y values are wrong -- it shows the largest value is about 1e+40. It looks like the lowest piece of the stack is scaled correctly,  then the subsequent pieces are drawn with the same scaling,  instead of being scaled properly for their positions in the stack.\r\n\r\n```\r\ndat <- data.frame(group=rep(LETTERS[ 1:4 ],  each=10), \r\n                  x=rep(1:10, 4), \r\n                  y=rep(10^(1:10), 4))\r\n\r\n# Linear scale\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=group)) + geom_area()\r\n\r\n# Log scale\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=group)) + geom_area() + scale_y_log10()\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nThe same happens with geom_bar:\r\n\r\n```\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=factor(x),  y=y,  fill=group)) + geom_bar()\r\n\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=factor(x),  y=y,  fill=group)) + geom_bar() + scale_y_log10()\r\n```\r\n", "title" : { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f8006489c" }, "comments" : 0, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2011-11-15T01:29:52Z", "number" : 261, "body" : "In the devel branch,  ggplot gives an error if the breaks on an axis go out of the plotting range.\r\n\r\n```\r\ndat <- data.frame(x=1:3,  y=1:3)\r\n\r\n# All breaks within range: OK\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point() +\r\n    scale_y_continuous(breaks=1:3,  labels=1:3)\r\n\r\n# Breaks go out of range: not OK\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point() +\r\n    scale_y_continuous(breaks=1:4,  labels=1:4)\r\n# Error in scale_labels.continuous(scale) : \r\n#  Breaks and labels are different lengths\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis can cause problems in cases where you want tell it to make tick marks,  say,  every 10,  without being super careful about the actual range shown in the graph. This happens especially when there are manually-specified labels to go with the breaks.\r\n\r\nI believe the release version didn't have this issue.", "assignee" : null, "title" : "Error if axis breaks go out of range", "labels" : [  ], "closed_at" : "2011-12-02T13:59:21Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/261", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/261/events", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/261", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/261/comments", "updated_at" : "2011-12-02T13:59:21Z", "state" : "closed", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/261/labels{ /name }", "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "id" : 86978, "login" : "wch" }, "id" : 2239037, "pull_request" : { "patch_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f8006489a" }, "comments" : 1, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2011-11-21T03:22:14Z", "number" : 263, "body" : "This is an issue with the development branch. In the release version,  when you use a log axis,  the tick labels will show in powers of base (e.g.,  e or 10) when you use the appropriate scale. In the development version,  the labels show as decimal numbers.\r\n\r\nIf you run this with the release version,  you'll see that the x axis labels are e^0,  e^2,  e^4 and so on. But if you run it in the devel version,  you'll see decimal values like 0.367,  7.389,  and so on.\r\n\r\n```\r\nset.seed(123)\r\ndat <- data.frame(x=exp(rnorm(100,  mean=4,  sd=2)),  y=rnorm(100))\r\n\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + geom_point() + scale_x_continuous(trans=\"log\")\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nThe same happens for `scale_x_log10`,  which is the only specially-named log scale in devel version. It also shows values in decimal (10,  100,  1000,  etc.) instead of powers of 10 (10^1,  10^2,  10^3,  etc.).\r\n\r\n```\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + geom_point() + scale_x_log10()\r\n```", "assignee" : null, "title" : "Log axes show decimal values for tick labels", "labels" : [  ], "closed_at" : "2011-11-21T13:26:44Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/263", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/263/events", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/263", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/263/comments", "updated_at" : "2011-11-21T13:26:44Z", "state" : "closed", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/263/labels{ /name }", "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "id" : 86978, "login" : "wch" }, "id" : 2301052, "pull_request" : { "patch_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

This works in the release version,  but it doesn't work in the devel version. This may also be true for other scales,  but I haven't tested them.\r\n\r\n\r\nThese examples are taken from the the help page. The first graph here looks the same in both versions,  but the second one has different colors in the release and devel version: \r\n\r\n```\r\np <- qplot(mpg,  wt,  data = mtcars,  colour = factor(cyl))\r\n\r\n# Same in both versions\r\np + scale_colour_manual(values = c(\"red\", \"blue\",  \"green\"))\r\n\r\n# Different in devel version - labeled elements have no effect\r\np + scale_colour_manual(values = c(\"8\" = \"red\", \"4\" = \"blue\", \"6\" = \"green\"))\r\n```\r\n\r\nIn the devel version,  4 is red,  6 is blue,  and 8 is green.\r\n\r\n\r\nSide note: It's unclear to me why `labels` are matched to `breaks` by position,  but `values` are matched to `breaks` by naming the vector elements. This code reverses the order of the legend. If `values` were matched by position,  the points for 8 cylinders,  in the upper left,  would be red with this code,  but they come out green,  in both the release and devel version.\r\n\r\n```\r\np + scale_colour_manual(breaks = c(8, 6, 4),  \r\n                        labels = c(\"Eight\", \"Six\", \"Four\"), \r\n                        values = c(\"red\", \"blue\", \"green\"))\r\n\r\n```\r\n", When using `geom_boxplot` with a continuous axis and specifying the `group`,  setting `width` has some inconsistent results.\r\n\r\nWhen there's a single data point in a group,  the box is centered on that point,  with the specified width. This means that one box can actually overlap with another even with the specified width is the same or smaller than the group size,  as in the example.\r\n\r\nWhen there is more than one point,  the width of the box is slightly less (0.8?) than the width of the actual data in the group.\r\n\r\n```R\r\nset.seed(113)\r\ndat <- data.frame(x=rnorm(50)^2,  y= rnorm(50))\r\n\r\nggplot(dat, aes(x=x, y=y)) + \r\n    geom_boxplot(aes(group=floor(x)),  width=1) + \r\n    geom_point(shape=21,  colour=\"blue\") # Distinguish these points from boxplot outliers\r\n```\r\n\r\nI'm not sure what the expected behavior should be,  so I can't provide a test.", "title" : "geom_boxplot: width with continuous axis has inconsistent results", "milestone" : { "due_on" : null, "state" : "open", code:\r\n\r\n```R\r\ntest_that(\"geom_boxplot range includes all outliers\",  { \r\n  dat <- data.frame(x=1,  y=c(-(1:20)^3,  (1:20)^3) )\r\n  p <- ggplot_build(ggplot(dat,  aes(x, y)) + { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f80064892" }, "comments" : 6, "milestone" : { "closed_issues" : 88, "created_at" : "2011-08-15T10:23:47Z", "number" : 1, "due_on" : null, "description" : "", "title" : "0.9", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/milestones/1", "state" : "closed", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/milestones/1/labels", "id" : 28360, "open_issues" : 0, "creator" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/repos", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/orgs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/7ba164f40a50bc23dbb2aa825fb7bc16?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/followers", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/received_events", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/following", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "7ba164f40a50bc23dbb2aa825fb7bc16", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/events{ /privacy }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/hadley/gists{ /gist_id }", "id" : 4196, "login" : "hadley" } }, "created_at" : "2011-12-04T21:33:20Z", "number" : 275, "body" : "This is only the tip of the iceberg as far as optimizing the drawing commands generated by ggplot2,  but this is the first thing that I've found that ggplot can directly control (most of the garbage is grid's fault).\r\n\r\nThe set of positions at which minor gridlines are drawn is a superset of the positions at which major gridlines are drawn.  Since the major gridlines are drawn second,  this has no effect on the *appearance* of the plot -- it just adds extra,  unnecessary draw operations to vector-device output.  As a blatant example,  consider\r\n\r\n    pdf(\"t.pdf\",  colormodel=\"gray\")\r\n    qplot(1,  1,  geom=\"point\")\r\n    dev.off()\r\n\r\nThe generated PDF draw commands include (some unrelated junk trimmed to make the problem clearer):\r\n\r\n    0.949 G 0.53 w\r\n    27.05 259.13 m 482.40 259.13 l S\r\n    254.72 28.67 m 254.72 489.60 l S\r\n    1.000 G 1.06 w\r\n    27.05 259.13 m 482.40 259.13 l S\r\n    254.72 28.67 m 254.72 489.60 l S\r\n\r\nThe first half of that is completely unnecessary.\r\n\r\nI think fixing this would be as easy as having guide_grid() filter from x.minor and y.minor all entries that duplicated entries in x.major and y.major respectively.", "assignee" : null, "title" : "Minor gridlines drawn underneath major gridlines", "labels" : [  ], "closed_at" : { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede89e892291f800646fa" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "updated_at" : "2012-07-26T15:39:05Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/280", "comments" : 3, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/280/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/280/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/280/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/280", "created_at" : "2011-12-07T07:15:47Z", "number" : 280, "body" : "With a a stacked area graph,  it requires an entry at every x for every group. If for a given x value,  one group doesn't have an entry in the data frame,  then it will behave as though the y value of that group at that x is zero.\r\n\r\nThe pictures will illustrate better:\r\n\r\n```R\r\n\r\ndat <- data.frame(\r\n        g=rep(LETTERS[ 1:3 ],  each=4), \r\n        x=rep(1:4,  3), \r\n        y=rep(3:14))\r\n\r\n# Remove row with g=B,  x=3 \r\ndat <- dat[ -7,  ] \r\ndat\r\n\r\n# Lines all look straight\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  colour=g)) + geom_line()\r\n\r\n# With a stacked area graph,  there's a dip at x=3 \r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=g)) + geom_area()\r\n```\r\n\r\nTest code:\r\n\r\n```R\r\ntest_that(\"Stacked area graph interpolates missing values\",  { \r\n  dat <- data.frame(\r\n           g=rep(LETTERS[ 1:3 ],  each=4), \r\n           x=rep(1:4,  3), \r\n           y=rep(3:14))\r\n\r\n  # Remove row with g=B,  x=3 \r\n  dat <- dat[ -7,  ] \r\n\r\n  p <- ggplot_build(ggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=g)) + geom_area())\r\n  \r\n  topgroup_y <- with(p$data[ [ 1 ] ],  y[ x==3 & group==3 ] )\r\n  expect_equal(topgroup_y,  27)  \r\n })\r\n```\r\n\r\nI think fixing this one would require doing some interpolation. Perhaps solving this one is better left to the large changes to stacking code in the future?", "title" : "Stacking for geom_area doesn't properly handle missing entries", "milestone" : { "due_on" : 35)\r\n\r\nboxplot(mpg ~ cyl,  mtcars)\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe output of `boxplot` seems to be consistent with `boxplot.stats`,  so my guess is that there's something wrong with geom_bar()\r\n```\r\n\r\nTest code:\r\n\r\n```R\r\ntest_that(\"coord_polar angles are evenly spaced when x is a factor\",  { \r\n  dat <- data.frame(x=LETTERS[ 1:3 ],  y=4)\r\n  p <- { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f8006488b" }, "comments" : 2, "milestone" : null, "created_at" : "2011-12-07T23:12:30Z", "number" : 283, "body" : "If you use points with size=0,  they're pretty much invisible if you output to bitmap files like PNG. But when you output to PDF,  they show up as large circles that are positioned with their upper-left corner at the specified x and y.\r\n\r\nYou generally won't use size 0 points,  but that was the only way I could get geom_boxplot to hide the outliers. The reason I wanted to do that was to overlay the box plots on a violin plot,  which is a standard thing to do.\r\n\r\n```R\r\nset.seed(123)\r\ndat <- data.frame(x=LETTERS[ 1:3 ],  y=rnorm(60))\r\n\r\np <- ggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y))\r\npdf('test.pdf',  width=3,  height=3)\r\np + geom_boxplot(outlier.size=0)\r\np + geom_point(size=0)\r\ndev.off()\r\n```\r\n\r\nI was able to get them to be effectively invisible by setting outlier.size=.01. Should this workaround be used,  or should I add an option to show/hide them,  like \"show.outliers\"? Some solution is necessary for box plots to be used with violins.", "assignee" : null, "title" : "Points with size 0 show up large and off-center in PDF files", "labels" : [  ], "closed_at" : "2011-12-09T06:21:45Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/283", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/283/events", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/283", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/283/comments", "updated_at" : "2011-12-09T06:21:45Z", "state" : "closed", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/283/labels{ /name }", "user" : { "type" : "User", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "id" : 86978, "login" : "wch" }, "id" : 2481573, "pull_request" : { "patch_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

I think this happens when the min or max value of data doesn't align with the break increments shown in the legend.\r\n\r\n```R\r\ndat <- data.frame(x=LETTERS[ 1:5 ],  y=1,  z=(1:5)/4)\r\ndat\r\n\r\n# Bad: Show's NA at high and low end\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=z)) + geom_bar()\r\n\r\n# Bad: Even with manual limits,  shows NA:\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=z)) + geom_bar() +\r\n    scale_fill_continuous(limits=c(0.25, 1.25))\r\n\r\n# OK: Set the breaks manually to specifically hit the values \r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=z)) + geom_bar() + \r\n    scale_fill_continuous(limits=c(0, 1.5),  breaks=seq(0.25, 1.25,  .25))\r\n\r\n# OK: set the limits at \"nice\" values\r\nggplot(dat,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  fill=z)) + geom_bar() +\r\n    scale_fill_continuous(limits=c(0, 1.5))\r\n```\r\n\r\nI'd write a test,  but I can't find legend information in the output of ggplot_build.", "assignee" : null, "title" : "scale_fill_continuous shows It's skeleton because I don't know exactly what to `expect`. \r\n\r\n```R\r\ntest_that('Continuous scales work with breaks=NA',  { \r\n  dat <- data.frame(x=1:3,  y=1:3)\r\n\r\n  px <- ggplot(dat, Someone emailed me asking about confidence intervals for loess fits. He was only able to get 68% confidence intervals.\r\n\r\nThese look the same:\r\n\r\n```R\r\nggplot(cars,  aes(x=speed,  y=dist)) + geom_point() + stat_smooth()\r\n\r\nggplot(cars,  aes(x=speed,  y=dist)) + geom_point() + stat_smooth(level=.2)\r\n```\r\n\r\nAccording to the docs for `predict.loess()`,  it doesn't actually support the `level` argument.\r\n\r\nIn `stat-smooth-methods.r`,  it looks like it's trying to make predictions with the `level` and `interval` arguments,  even though they're not supported by `predict.loess`.\r\n\r\n```R\r\npredictdf.loess <- function(model,  xseq,  se,  level) { \r\n  pred <- stats::predict(model,  newdata = data.frame(x = xseq),  se = se, \r\n    level = level,  interval = if(se) \"confidence\" else \"none\")\r\n...\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe docs for stat_smooth say that you can change the level -- if this isn't actually possible for loess,  then it should probably be noted.\r\n\r\nAlso,  it looks like `predict.loess` isn't exported from `stats`,  even though other predict functions are. I wonder if that's a bug.\r\n\r\n```R\r\n> stats::predict.loess\r\nError: 'predict.loess' is not an exported object from 'namespace:stats'\r\n\r\n> stats::predict.lm\r\nfunction (object,  newdata,  se.fit = FALSE,  scale = NULL,  df = Inf,  \r\n    interval = c(\"none\",  \"confidence\",  \"prediction\"),  level = 0.95,  \r\n...\r\n...\r\n```\r\n", "assignee" : null, "title" : "stat_smooth: This then results in a request for an inordinate amount of RAM which causes qplot to fail.\r\n\r\nHere is a small reproduce:\r\n\r\n```\r\n> a <- data.frame( x = c( 1351425 ,  2865880767 ,  1351425 ,  2865880767 ) ,  y = c( 0.0254 ,  -0.370578048780488 ,  -0.399846341463415 ,  0.613065853658537 ) )\r\n> b <- qplot( x ,  y ,  data = a ,  geom = \"hex\" )\r\n> print( b )\r\nError in vector(\"integer\",  length) : vector size specified is too large\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe offending lines of code follow:\r\n\r\n```\r\n> grep -Rn round_any ggplot2/R/stat-binhex.r\r\n\r\n61:    round_any(min(x),  binwidth[ 1 ],  floor) - 1e-6, \r\n62:    round_any(max(x),  binwidth[ 1 ],  ceiling) + 1e-6\r\n67:    round_any(min(y),  binwidth[ 1 ],  floor) - 1e-6, \r\n68:    round_any(max(y), Hopefully this isn't a problem. I tested merging everything into the current hadley/master branch,  and it seems to work.\r\n\r\n\r\nSome things are strange because of dots are visually stacked. Notes:\r\n\r\n* When binning along x axis,  the y dimensions are arbitrary. This is because the vertical positioning of the the dots is done by the grob. I don't think it's possible to have correct y dimensions with ggplot2. (Something similar happens when binning along y axis,  but the width is set so that each cluster will be dodged properly.)\r\n* For the same reasons,  the y axis label and tick labels aren't meaningful.\r\n* When binning along x axis,  pos_stack doesn't work because of the strange y dimensions. Stacking wouldn't be impossible to implement,  but it would be a big hack (and it wouldn't use pos_stack).\r\n* There is a fair bit of complexity. Part of it is because binning can be done on x or y,  and part of it is because there are two methods of binning. Instead of adding the \"histodot\" option,  I'd prefer to simply use stat_bin,  but it doesn't allow binning along the y axis.\r\n\r\nI'm going to try to implement the smoothing algorithm from Wilkinson (1999) p. 6,  but I find it confusing at the moment.\r\n\r\nSome examples here:\r\nhttps://github.com/wch/ggplot2/wiki/geom_dotplot", "assignee" : null, "title" : "Feature/wdotplot", variable,  but does not have any rows of data,  an error is thrown.\r\n\r\n# Reproducible example\r\n\r\n```r\r\nempty <- data.frame(x=numeric(0),  y=numeric(0))\r\nnotempty <- data.frame(x=1,  y=1)\r\n\r\nggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n    geom_point() +\r\n    geom_point(data=empty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n\r\nggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n    geom_point() +\r\n    geom_point(data=notempty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n\r\nggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n    geom_point(data=empty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n\r\nggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n    geom_point(data=notempty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n\r\nggplot()+\r\n    geom_point(data=empty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n\r\nggplot()+\r\n    geom_point(data=notempty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n\r\nggplot(empty,  aes(x=x, y=y))+\r\n    geom_point()\r\n```\r\n\r\n# Results\r\n\r\n```r\r\n> empty <- data.frame(x=numeric(0),  y=numeric(0))\r\n> notempty <- data.frame(x=1,  y=1)\r\n> \r\n> ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n+     geom_point() +\r\n+     geom_point(data=empty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\nError in eval(expr,  envir,  enclos) : object 'x' not found\r\n> \r\n> ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n+     geom_point() +\r\n+     geom_point(data=notempty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n> \r\n> ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n+     geom_point(data=empty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\nError in eval(expr,  envir,  enclos) : object 'x' not found\r\n> \r\n> ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=mpg,  y=wt)) +\r\n+     geom_point(data=notempty,  mapping=aes(x=x, y=y))\r\n> The second plot works as expected\r\n1. The third plot maybe should throw an error,  but not that error. `x` is in `empty`,  but there is no data to plot.\r\n1. The fourth works as expected.\r\n1. The fifth should behave like the third.\r\n1. The sixth works as expected.\r\n1. The seventh should also behave like the third.\r\n\r\n# sessionInfo\r\n\r\n```r\r\n> sessionInfo()\r\nR version 2.14.0 (2011-10-31)\r\nPlatform: i386-pc-mingw32/i386 (32-bit)\r\n\r\nlocale:\r\n[ 1 ] LC_COLLATE=English_United States.1252 \r\n[ 2 ] LC_CTYPE=English_United States.1252   \r\n[ 3 ] LC_MONETARY=English_United States.1252\r\n[ 4 ] LC_NUMERIC=C                          \r\n[ 5 ] LC_TIME=English_United States.1252    \r\n\r\nattached base packages:\r\n[ 1 ] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n\r\nother attached packages:\r\n[ 1 ] ggplot2_0.9.0 devtools_0.4 \r\n\r\nloaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n [ 1 ] colorspace_1.1-0   dichromat_1.2-3    digest_0.5.1       grid_2.14.0       \r\n [ 5 ] MASS_7.3-16        memoise_0.1        munsell_0.3        plyr_1.6          \r\n [ 9 ] proto_0.3-9.2      RColorBrewer_1.0-5 RCurl_1.8-0.1      reshape2_1.2      \r\n[ 13 ] scales_0.1.0       stringr_0.6       \r\n```\r\n\r\nThis \"0.9.0\" is commit 16e69f6348. { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede89e892291f800646f8" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "updated_at" : "2012-01-23T13:48:05Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/357", "comments" : 5, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/357/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/357/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/357/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/357", "created_at" : "2012-01-18T08:47:52Z", "number" : 357, "body" : "\r\nExample:\r\n\r\n\td <- data.frame(size=c(\"S\",  \"M\",  \"L\",  \"XL\"),  value=c(3, 6, 7, 9),  stringsAsFactors=FALSE)\r\n\tclass(d$size)\r\n\tggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x=size,  y=value))\r\n\r\nHere the order in the plot is L,  M,  S,  XL: the alphabetical order. I guess ggplot converts `d$size` into a factor even though I forced it to be a character vector.\r\n\r\nI think that when categorical data are coded as factors,  of course ggplot should use the levels' order.\r\n\r\nWhen data is of categorical nature but not explicitely coded as a factor,  ggplot should respect the order in the original data because it often has a meaning. It is the expectation of novice users at least and,  for those users also,  it is often conceptually easier to reorder the original data than to change the order of levels in a factor.\r\n\r\nIn practice,  when converting the data for the plot,  ggplot should do\r\n\r\n    converted <- factor(mydata,  levels=unique(mydata))\r\n\r\nIf you point be towards where the data is initially handled,  I might even be able to fix this myself.\r\n", "title" : "Categorial variables not specified explicitly as factors should be ordered as they are in the original data", "milestone" : { "due_on" : null, "state" : "open", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/milestones/3/labels", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/milestones/3", "created_at" : Of course this can create hedge cases when the vector specifying the facets is completely different from the data source of the layers. But I guess that,  to achieve this:\r\n\r\n    ggplot() + geom_point(aes(x=d$x,  y=d$y))\r\n\r\nsomewhere,  ggplot creates a temporary data set for the point layer. { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede8be892291f8006483d" }, "updated_at" : "2012-01-23T16:21:47Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "closed", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/364/comments", "closed_at" : "2012-01-23T16:21:42Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/364", "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/364.diff", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/364", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/364.patch" }, "comments" : 6, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/364/labels{ /name }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/364", "created_at" : "2012-01-20T21:40:53Z", "number" : 364, "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/364/events", "body" : "This addresses #361. It adds a function to find what a coordinate transforms maps x and y to -- for example,  x and y; y and x; or theta and x.\r\n\r\nThis makes it possible to have a general method to find the ranges of the x and y,  even after transformation.\r\n\r\n\r\n* I don't really like the method name I used,  `coord_find_varmapping()` but I couldn't think of a better one. I'm open to suggestions.\r\n* It gets,  for example,  scale$theta.range by using a string,  as in scale[ [ 'theta.range' ] ]. I know this isn't the best...\r\n* I updated abline,  hline,  and vline to use it. Now these work with coord_flip and coord_polar,  with the exception of abline with polar. Actually,  it works,  but it doesn't wrap around infinitely like it should.\r\n* I also added visual tests for abline,  hline,  and vline. Here are two examples. The first seems right,  the second doesn't.\r\n\r\n```\r\n> dist_central_angle(lat=c(-90, 90),  lon=c(-45, -45))\r\n[ 1 ] 3.141593\r\n\r\n> dist_central_angle(lat=c(45, 45),  lon=c(0, 180))\r\n[ 1 ] 0\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nInside the function,  the distance seems to be calculated by this line of code - but it doesn't use `lon` at all,  only `lat`:\r\n\r\n```\r\n  ahav(sqrt(hav(diff(lat)) + cos(lat[ -n ]) * cos(lat[ -1 ]) * hav(diff(lat))))\r\n```\r\n", "title" : "dist_central_angle gives wrong values", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "login" : "wch", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "id" : 86978, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following" }, "id" : 2923392, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
