However,  after trying some simple fixes suggested by Hadley and Winston,  this superficial bug disappeared to reveal a namespace issue no reflected in the title of this issue tracker post.\n\n\"\nWhy does this appear when trying to plot/render a ggplot object using v0.9.2?\n\nDefault print/show/plot for ggplot object now results in a prompt:\n```\nHit <Return> to see next plot:\n```\nrather than just rendering the graphic.\n\nThat is,  `show(p)` used to be indistinguishable from `print(p)`,  and both would automatically produce a graphic on the default graphic device. Now `show(p)` et al result in the above prompt. Unfortunately,  this is stalling some of my ggplot2-dependent function examples. I have not seen this in previous versions.\n\"\n\nNote that the `print(p)` problem could be fixed with `library(ggplot2)`,  and that this was one of the indications of the namespace change in v0.9.2 of ggplot2.", "title" : "`Imports:` dependency no longer sufficient for dependent package plotting", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "8679dfbc0d277b5a840e4101a6b51630", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "login" : "joey711", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/repos", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/events{ /privacy }", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/orgs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8679dfbc0d277b5a840e4101a6b51630?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/received_events", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/followers", "id" : 841437, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/joey711/following" }, "id" : 6779335, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede89e892291f800646b8" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "updated_at" : "2012-10-15T13:55:28Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/688", "comments" : 3, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/688/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/688/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/688/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/688", "created_at" : "2012-10-11T20:56:34Z", "number" : 688, "body" : "I started this issue as a question in StackOverflow:\r\nhttp://stackoverflow.com/questions/12806260/how-to-enforce-ggplots-position-dodge-on-categories-with-no-data\r\n\r\nI'm trying to obtain boxplots of two different signals (ind) sharing the same categories (cat).  When there is a category with data for one signal but not for the other one,  the boxplot for the signal with data covers all the horizontal spacing,  and does not respect the position_dodge instruction for that particular category.  As you can see on the example below,  the signal x has no data for category B,  so it loses the space reserved by position_dodge.\r\n\r\nThanks in advance.\r\n\r\n    data<-data.frame(cat=c('A', 'A', 'A', 'A', 'B', 'B', 'A', 'A', 'A', 'A', 'B', 'B'),  \r\n                     values=c(3, 2, 1, 4, NA, NA, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9),  \r\n                     ind=c('x', 'x', 'x', 'x', 'x', 'x', 'y', 'y', 'y', 'y', 'y', 'y'))\r\n\r\n    print(ggplot() +\r\n            scale_colour_hue(guide='none') +\r\n          geom_boxplot(\r\n               aes(x=as.factor(cat),  y=values,  \r\n                   fill=ind),  \r\n               position=position_dodge(width=.60),  \r\n               data=data, \r\n               outlier.size = 1.2, \r\n               na.rm=T))\r\n\r\n![ graph with original problem ][ 1 ]\r\n\r\n\r\nHere is what I have attempted so far:\r\n\r\n1.  I first tried to change the color of boxes with missing data.  I couldn't figure out how to directly inject the desired color for a single box,  as color information is automatically generated from signals (fill = data$ind in this case).\r\n\r\n2.  Since that did not work,  I exaggerated the dummy values out of the normal y-axis range (-1000),  and I found something interesting happening that looks like a ggplot2 bug:\r\n\r\nHere is the example data with a dummy value for the category with missing data:\r\n\r\n    data            <- data.frame(\r\n    cat=c('A', 'A', 'A', 'A', 'B', 'B', 'A', 'A', 'A', 'A', 'B', 'B', 'B'),  \r\n    values=c(3, 2, 1, 4, NA, NA, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9,  -1000),  \r\n    ind=c('x', 'x', 'x', 'x', 'x', 'x', 'y', 'y', 'y', 'y', 'y', 'y', 'x'))\r\n\r\n    p  <- ggplot() +\r\n          scale_colour_hue(guide='none') +\r\n          geom_boxplot(aes(x=as.factor(cat),  y=values,  fill=ind), \r\n          position=position_dodge(width=.60),  \r\n          data=data, \r\n          outlier.size = 1.2, \r\n          na.rm=T)\r\n\r\nAs shown below,  printing the plot as it is without defining y-axis limits,  we get the correct behavior on the x-axis.  Of course the undesired dummy boxplot will also show up.\r\n\r\n    print(p)\r\n\r\n![ with no y-axis limits ][ 2 ]\r\n\r\nBut if we add the y limits,  we still get the original undesired behavior.\r\n\r\n    print(p + ylim(0,  10))\r\n\r\n![ with y-axis limits ][ 3 ]\r\n\r\n\r\n  [ 1 ]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/rKbeq.png\r\n  [ 2 ]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/M3rXi.png\r\n  [ 3 ]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/FldHV.png", "title" : "Automatic dodging or position_dodge not enforced on boxplots with missing values", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "fd590883e86f1933306de8260a8e6b84", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "login" : "josian", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/events{ /privacy }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/fd590883e86f1933306de8260a8e6b84?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/received_events", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/orgs", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/followers", "id" : 585791, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/josian/following" }, "id" : 7526508, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

I noticed when writing themes that using `theme_gray()`or `theme_bw()` as the base theme required finding which non-top level elements were defined by those themes.   `theme_base0` is a  complete theme that only defines top-level elements.  `theme_base_sizes` defines various size elements that are used in `theme_gray`,  and users are less likely to want to alter than colors.  `theme_base` combines `theme_base0` and `theme_base_sizes`.", "title" : "New themes suitable for extending", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "543dc4a614a0c26a4fdec9a7c51a746d", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "login" : "jrnold", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/events{ /privacy }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/543dc4a614a0c26a4fdec9a7c51a746d?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/received_events", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/orgs", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/followers", "id" : 123968, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/jrnold/following" }, "id" : 7577777, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede89e892291f800646b5" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/693.diff", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/693", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/693.patch" }, "updated_at" : "2012-10-15T16:33:35Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/693", "comments" : 2, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/693/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/693/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/693/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/693", "created_at" : "2012-10-14T20:57:24Z", "number" : 693, "body" : "I added new print methods for `theme` and `element` objects which are easier to understand than the existing methods.  Additionally,  the output of print can be evaluated to recreate the object. This makes it easy to create a new theme by printing an existing theme and making edits to the output. \r\n\r\nExample of print output for `theme_gray`\r\n\r\n``` r-console\r\n> print(theme_gray()$rect)\r\nelement(fill = \"white\",  colour = \"black\",  size = 0.5,  linetype = 1) \r\n> print(theme_gray())\r\ntheme(line = element(colour = \"black\",  size = 0.5,  linetype = 1,  lineend = \"butt\"), \r\nrect = element(fill = \"white\",  colour = \"black\",  size = 0.5,  linetype = 1), \r\ntext = element(family = \"\",  face = \"plain\",  colour = \"black\",  size = 12,  hjust = 0.5,  vjust = 0.5,  angle = 0,  lineheight = 0.9), \r\naxis.text = element(colour = \"grey50\",  size = rel(0.8)), \r\nstrip.text = element(size = rel(0.8)), \r\naxis.line = element(), \r\naxis.text.x = element(vjust = 1), \r\naxis.text.y = element(hjust = 1), \r\naxis.ticks = element(colour = \"grey50\"), \r\naxis.title.x = element(), \r\naxis.title.y = element(angle = 90), \r\naxis.ticks.length = unit(0.15,  \"cm\"), \r\naxis.ticks.margin = unit(0.1,  \"cm\"), \r\nlegend.background = element(colour = NA), \r\nlegend.margin = unit(0.2,  \"cm\"), \r\nlegend.key = element(fill = \"grey95\",  colour = \"white\"), \r\nlegend.key.size = unit(1.2,  \"lines\"), \r\nlegend.key.height = NULL, \r\nlegend.key.width = NULL, \r\nlegend.text = element(size = rel(0.8)), \r\nlegend.text.align = NULL, \r\nlegend.title = element(face = \"bold\",  size = rel(0.8),  hjust = 0), \r\nlegend.title.align = NULL, \r\nlegend.position = \"right\", \r\nlegend.direction = NULL, \r\nlegend.justification = \"center\", \r\nlegend.box = NULL, \r\npanel.background = element(fill = \"grey90\",  colour = NA), \r\npanel.border = element(), \r\npanel.grid.major = element(colour = \"white\"), \r\npanel.grid.minor = element(colour = \"grey95\",  size = 0.25), \r\npanel.margin = unit(0.25,  \"lines\"), \r\nstrip.background = element(fill = \"grey80\",  colour = NA), \r\nstrip.text.x = element(), \r\nstrip.text.y = element(angle = -90), \r\nplot.background = element(colour = \"white\"), \r\nplot.title = element(size = rel(1.2)), \r\nplot.margin = unit(c(1,  1,  0.5,  0.5),  \"lines\"), \r\ncomplete = TRUE) \r\n```\r\n\r\nThe print output evaluates to the original object.\r\n\r\n``` r-console\r\n> identical(eval(parse(text=as.character(theme_gray()))),  theme_gray())\r\nTRUE\r\n```\r\n", "title" : "improved print methods for theme and element classes", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : First is `geom_polygon`,  then `geom_path`:\r\n\r\n```R\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\nlibrary(maps)\r\nsystem.time(print(ggplot(map_data(\"world\")) + geom_polygon(aes(long,  lat,  group = group))))\r\n#   user  system elapsed \r\n# 11.701   0.247  46.543 \r\nsystem.time(print(ggplot(map_data(\"world\")) + geom_path(aes(long,  lat,  group = group))))\r\n#   user  system elapsed \r\n#  2.802   0.123   3.044\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nThese are the times after the fix:\r\n\r\n```R\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\nlibrary(maps)\r\nsystem.time(print(ggplot(map_data(\"world\")) + geom_polygon(aes(long,  lat,  group = group))))\r\n#   user  system elapsed \r\n#  0.922   0.098   1.157 \r\nsystem.time(print(ggplot(map_data(\"world\")) + geom_path(aes(long,  lat,  group = group))))\r\n#   user  system elapsed \r\n#  3.038   0.146   3.319 \r\n```\r\n\r\n`geom_polygon` is now about 12.5x faster than it was before -- and it's now 3x faster than `geom_path`. Not bad!\r\n\r\n\r\nAll the tests pass,  and visual tests are unchanged (which is a little surprising -- I would have expected the change in polygon grouping to result in some changes to the PDF).",   = element_blank(), \r\n      axis.line        = element_line(colour = \"black\"), \r\n      panel.grid.major = element_blank(), \r\n      panel.grid.minor = element_blank()\r\n    )\r\n { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede89e892291f800646ae" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "updated_at" : "2012-10-26T15:56:24Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/707", "comments" : 0, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/707/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/707/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/707/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/707", "created_at" : "2012-10-26T15:56:24Z", "number" : 707, "body" : "I'm interested in being able to plot confidence intervals/bands for step functions (such as nonparametric estimated survival curves) using geom_ribbon. I've hacked up a solution using geom_rect,  but I thought it would be nice if I could use geom_ribbon instead.\r\n\r\nHere is an example using geom_rect:\r\n```R\r\nlibrary(survival)\r\naml.fit = survfit(Surv(time,  status) ~ 1,  data = aml)\r\naml.gg = do.call(data.frame, \r\n                 summary(aml.fit)[ c('time',  'surv',  'lower',  'upper') ])\r\naml.rect = aml.gg[ -nrow(aml.gg),   ]\r\naml.rect$timemax = aml.gg$time[ -1 ]\r\nggplot(aml.gg) +\r\n  geom_step(aes(x = time,  y = surv)) +\r\n  geom_rect(data = aml.rect, \r\n            aes(xmin = time,  xmax = timemax,  ymin = lower,  ymax = upper), \r\n            alpha = 0.1)\r\n```\r\nHere is how I would hope to use geom_ribbon instead:\r\n```R\r\nggplot(aml.gg) +\r\n  geom_step(aes(x = time,  y = surv)) +\r\n { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede89e892291f800646ab" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "updated_at" : "2012-11-02T15:21:39Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/713", "comments" : 1, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/713/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/713/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/713/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/713", "created_at" : "2012-10-29T23:14:25Z", "number" : 713, "body" : "When passing specifying certain arguments to functions and passing the rest from the calling function via `...`,  reliance on positional matching of arguments rather than using named arguments can lead to the wrong arguments being assigned to the wrong formals.\r\n\r\nThis issue came to light in a discussion about the `palette` argument to `discrete_scale` which is not available to,  for example,  `scale_shape_discrete` (see https://groups.google.com/d/topic/ggplot2/XeC40tWpIPw/discussion). \r\n\r\nUsing `scale_shape` as an example because it is simple:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nscale_shape <- function(...,  solid = TRUE) { \r\n  discrete_scale(\"shape\",  \"shape_d\",  shape_pal(solid),  ...)\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe first three arguments to `discrete_scale` are `aesthetics`,  `scale_name`,  and `palette`. If an argument is specified with any of these names in the `scale_shape` call,  it will preferentially be matched to the named argument (according to the rules of argument matching). The given unnamed arguments are then assigned positionally to the remaining arguments and so do not get to the right place. This was the problem in the mailing list discussion referenced above.\r\n\r\nNote especially the value of the `name` element:\r\n\r\n```r\r\n> p.test <- function(n) {  21:(20+n)  }\r\n> dput(scale_shape(palette=p.test))\r\nstructure(list(call = discrete_scale(aesthetics = \"shape\",  scale_name = \"shape_d\",  \r\n    palette = ..1,  name = shape_pal(solid)),  aesthetics = \"shape\",  \r\n    scale_name = \"shape_d\",  palette = function (n) \r\n    { \r\n        21:(20 + n)\r\n     },  range = <S4 object of class structure(\"DiscreteRange\",  package = \"scales\")>,  \r\n    limits = NULL,  na.value = NA,  expand = structure(list(),  class = \"waiver\"),  \r\n    name = function (n) \r\n    { \r\n        if (n > 6) { \r\n            msg <- paste(\"The shape palette can deal with a maximum of 6 discrete \",  \r\n                \"values because more than 6 becomes difficult to discriminate; \",  \r\n                \"you have \",  n,  \". Consider specifying shapes manually. if you \",  \r\n                \"must have them.\",  sep = \"\")\r\n            warning(paste(strwrap(msg),  collapse = \"\\n\"),  call. = FALSE)\r\n         }\r\n        if (solid) { \r\n            c(16,  17,  15,  3,  7,  8)[ seq_len(n) ]\r\n         }\r\n        else { \r\n            c(1,  2,  0,  3,  7,  8)[ seq_len(n) ]\r\n         }\r\n     },  breaks = structure(list(),  class = \"waiver\"),  labels = structure(list(),  class = \"waiver\"),  \r\n    legend = NULL,  drop = TRUE,  guide = \"legend\"),  .Names = c(\"call\",  \r\n\"aesthetics\",  \"scale_name\",  \"palette\",  \"range\",  \"limits\",  \"na.value\",  \r\n\"expand\",  \"name\",  \"breaks\",  \"labels\",  \"legend\",  \"drop\",  \"guide\"\r\n),  class = c(\"shape_d\",  \"discrete\",  \"scale\"))\r\n> str(scale_shape(palette=p.test))\r\nList of 14\r\n $ call      : language discrete_scale(aesthetics = \"shape\",  scale_name = \"shape_d\",  palette = ..1,       name = shape_pal(solid))\r\n $ aesthetics: chr \"shape\"\r\n $ scale_name: chr \"shape_d\"\r\n $ palette   :function (n)  \r\n  ..- attr(*,  \"srcref\")=Class 'srcref'  atomic [ 1:8 ] 1 11 1 35 11 35 1 1\r\n  .. .. ..- attr(*,  \"srcfile\")=Classes 'srcfilecopy',  'srcfile' <environment: 0x000000001f0dabc0> \r\n $ range     :Reference class 'DiscreteRange' [ package \"scales\" ] with 1 fields\r\n  ..$ range: NULL\r\n  ..and 14 methods,  of which 3 are possibly relevant:\r\n  ..  initialize,  reset,  train\r\n $ limits    : NULL\r\n $ na.value  : logi NA\r\n $ expand    : list()\r\n  ..- attr(*,  \"class\")= chr \"waiver\"\r\n $ name      :function (n)  \r\n $ breaks    : list()\r\n  ..- attr(*,  \"class\")= chr \"waiver\"\r\n $ labels    : list()\r\n  ..- attr(*,  \"class\")= chr \"waiver\"\r\n $ legend    : NULL\r\n $ drop      : logi TRUE\r\n $ guide     : chr \"legend\"\r\n - attr(*,  \"class\")= chr [ 1:3 ] \"shape_d\" \"discrete\" \"scale\"\r\n```\r\nIf `scale_shape` was instead defined as\r\n\r\n```r\r\nscale_shape <- function(...,  solid = TRUE) { \r\n  discrete_scale(aesthetics = \"shape\",  scale_name = \"shape_d\",  palette = shape_pal(solid),  ...)\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\nThen at least specifying `palette` in the `scale_shape` call would fail sooner with:\r\n\r\n```r\r\np.test <- function(n) {  21:(20+n)  }\r\n> scale_shape(palette=p.test)\r\nError in discrete_scale(aesthetics = \"shape\",  scale_name = \"shape_d\",   : \r\n  formal argument \"palette\" matched by multiple actual arguments\r\n```\r\n\r\nIdeally,  the `...` argument would be parsed and any disallowed values would be ignored or warned about.  Perhaps something like\r\n\r\n```r\r\nscale_shape <- function(...,  solid = TRUE) { \r\n  dots <- list(...)\r\n  dots[ [ \"aesthetics\" ] ] <- \"shape\"\r\n  dots[ [ \"scale_name\" ] ] <- \"shape_d\"\r\n  dots[ [ \"palette\" ] ] <- shape_pal(solid)\r\n  do.call(\"discrete_scale\",  dots)\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\nAll instances that pass `...` on to other functions and rely on positional matching of arguments need to be assessed. \r\n", "title" : "Reliance on positional matching when also passing ... is error prone", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "b03b24d83939c4e11735af5340d90409", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "login" : "BrianDiggs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/events{ /privacy }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b03b24d83939c4e11735af5340d90409?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/received_events", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/orgs", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/followers", "id" : 463252, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/following" }, "id" : 7954423, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

This was the case in 0.8.9,  but has not been in 0.9.0 onward. I believe it should be the case again.\n\n# Example code\n\n    DF <- expand.grid(A = c(\"A\", \"B\"),  B = c(\"a\",  \"b\"))\n    DF$y <- seq_len(nrow(DF))\n    DF$B <- factor(DF$B,  levels=rev(levels(DF$B)))\n\n    ggplot(DF,  aes(x=A,  y=y,  fill=B)) +\n        geom_bar(stat=\"identity\")\n\nIn this,  the bars are stacked with \"a\" on the bottom. The expected behavior can be achieved with \n\n    ggplot(DF,  aes(x=A,  y=y,  fill=B,  order=B)) +\n      geom_bar(stat=\"identity\")\n\nHowever,  in the absence of a defined order,  the order of the factor levels should be used.\n\nThe commit which changed this behavior is e2291558a6282bbf18c0ef8b70907c7ebd3bd8df\n", "title" : "Default when order is not specifiied is not the ordering of the factors", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "b03b24d83939c4e11735af5340d90409", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "login" : "BrianDiggs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/events{ /privacy }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b03b24d83939c4e11735af5340d90409?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/received_events", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/orgs", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/followers", "id" : 463252, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/following" }, "id" : 8436122, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50bede89e892291f800646a2" }, "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "updated_at" : "2012-11-21T16:47:19Z", "assignee" : null, "state" : "open", "closed_at" : null, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/723", "comments" : 1, "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/723/labels{ /name }", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/723/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/723/comments", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/723", "created_at" : "2012-11-20T04:16:19Z", "number" : 723, "body" : "Not sure if this is entirely possible,  but at the moment,  there's no way to apply different scales to different layers. Arguably this is a good thing,  because it stops people doing stupid things,  but I am of the mind that rope is just a tool,  and if some people feel like hanging themselves,  that shouldn't stop the rest of us using it for something sensible. \n\nMy example: I need to create a figure similar to the one at https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/figure-ts-23.html : multiple model time-series,  with an observations time series,  and a mean (I actually need to show 3 different means). To do this,  at the moment,  basically requires giving each dataset (models,  observations,  means) an extra variable that identifies the data type,  so that a colour can be applied to each type. This get *really* messy once you start needing multiple versions of each figure (ie. some with less data showing,  some in greyscale,  etc.),  because `scale_color_manual` can only be applied once for a whole graph. If layers could be named,  then you could do something like this:\n\n    ggplot(models,  aes(x=year,  y=temp,  group=model)) + geom_line()\n      + scale_colour_manual(layer='base',  values=c('yellow'))\n      + geom_line(data=mean,  layer='mean') + scale_colour_manual(layer='mean',  values=c('red'))\n      + geom_line(data=obs,  layer='obs') + scale_colour_manual(layer='obs',  values=c('black'))\n\nWhich would make it *really easy* and intuitive to remove parts of the graph: just comment out a line - the order of the colour scale doesn't have to change. It also makes it easier to change the colour (or size,  or linetype etc.),  as the colours are visually mapped to specific datasets in the code (you don't have a single `scale_colour_manual(values=c('black',  'red',  'yellow'))` that you have to remember the order of).\n\nDoes that make sense? ", "title" : "Allow named layers", "milestone" : null, "labels" : [  ], "user" : { "type" : "User", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/subscriptions", "gravatar_id" : "20cb8dcc17ad4334c0f8cb1ddc28bcd0", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "login" : "naught101", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/events{ /privacy }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/gists{ /gist_id }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/20cb8dcc17ad4334c0f8cb1ddc28bcd0?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/received_events", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/orgs", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/followers", "id" : 167164, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/naught101/following" }, "id" : 8492557, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50c95511edecb5117100060e" }, "created_at" : "2012-12-05T18:19:01Z", "assignee" : null, "title" : "No path with stat=\"summary\"", "closed_at" : null, "number" : 732, "body" : "Thank you for all the good work.\r\n\r\nThis comes from a discussion on google group:\r\nhttps://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=#!search/With$20stat=%22summary%22, $20fun.y=%22mean%22$20get$20%22Each$20group$20consist$20of$20only$20one$20observation%22/ggplot2/ECI59jsdOYc/CCm1MOxXnhEJ\r\n\r\nExamples:\r\n```R\r\nd <- qplot(cyl,  mpg,  data=mtcars)\r\nd + geom_line(stat=\"summary\",  fun.y=\"mean\")\r\n```\r\nor\r\n```R\r\nstat_sum_single <- function(fun,  geom=\"point\",  ...) { \r\n  stat_summary(fun.y=fun,  colour=\"red\",  geom=geom,  size = 3,  ...)\r\n }\r\n\r\nd + stat_sum_single(mean,  geom=\"line\",  aes(group=as.character(cyl)))\r\n```\r\nor\r\n```R\r\nggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=cyl,  y=mpg)) +\r\n  geom_point() +\r\n  stat_summary(fun.y=mean,  geom=\"line\",  aes(group=factor(cyl)))\r\n```\r\n\r\nor\r\n...\r\n\r\n\r\nall give\r\n\"geom_path: Each group consist of only one observation. { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50c95511edecb51171000608" }, "created_at" : "2012-12-11T21:05:44Z", "assignee" : null, "title" : "Improved aesthetic documentation", "closed_at" : null, "number" : 740, "body" : "This wishlist item is inspired by a recent issue (Issue #726),  an email on the help list  (https://groups.google.com/d/topic/ggplot2/4rVJ1xWsLeQ/discussion),  and some previous work I have done (Issue #717).\r\n\r\nI think the documentation of aesthetics themselves needs to be overhauled/improved and I wanted to create this issue to put down some of my ideas. This has always been a thin part of the documentation. The ggplot2 book has it as Appendix B which is only 3 pages. JakeRuss added documentation of linetype,  size,  shape,  colour,  fill,  and alpha in June 2011. Documentation for position,  order,  and group was added in January 2012. But is is jumbled and not well linked.\r\n\r\nHere are my suggestions:\r\n\r\n* Rename the documents/topics to start with \"aesthetic\" rather than \"aes\" to distinguish them from the `aes` family of functions (`aes`,  `aes_string`,  `aes_all`,  `aes_auto`).\r\n* Divide the documentation into separate topics for each aesthetic. *Very* closely related concepts (such as the position aesthetics,  `hjust` and `vjust`,  `colour` and `fill`) can be kept together,  but `shape` and `linetype` don't belong together. For the cases with combined documentation,  there should be aliases to each separately (aesthetic-hjust,  for example).\r\n* Document all the aesthetics\r\n\r\n    ```r\r\n> unique(names(aes_all(ggplot2:::.all_aesthetics)))\r\n [ 1 ] \"hjust\"      \"alpha\"      \"angle\"      \"fill\"       \"size\"      \r\n [ 6 ] \"colour\"     \"group\"      \"label\"      \"linetype\"   \"lower\"     \r\n[ 11 ] \"ymax\"       \"middle\"     \"ymin\"       \"order\"      \"shape\"     \r\n[ 16 ] \"radius\"     \"sample\"     \"upper\"      \"vjust\"      \"weight\"    \r\n[ 21 ] \"width\"      \"x\"          \"xend\"       \"xmax\"       \"xmin\"      \r\n[ 26 ] \"xintercept\" \"y\"          \"yend\"       \"yintercept\" \"z\"         \r\n    ```\r\n\r\nTaking out those already documented,  that leaves `hjust`,  `angle`,  `label`,  `lower`,   `middle`,  `radius`,  `sample`,  `upper`,  `vjust`,  `weight`,  `width`,  and `z` (and,  according to `geom_text`,   `family`,  `fontface` and `lineheight`; are there others?)\r\n* In the list of aesthetics in each geom,  add links for each to its corresponding aesthetic page (the consistent naming and/or aliasing based on the aesthetic should make this template-able)\r\n\r\nUltimately,  this will address the problem of \"what does that aesthetic control?\" or \"why would I want to set that?\" or the reverse questions of \"what aesthetic controls such-and-such aspect of the plot?\"\r\n\r\nIf anyone else thinks this could be useful,  I'll make a branch on my clone of the repository and attach it as a pull request to which people can comment an contribute.", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/740", "labels" : [  ], "updated_at" : "2012-12-11T21:06:34Z", "labels_url" : #These are all identical\r\n    p + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(hjust = 0))\r\n    p + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(hjust = 0.5))\r\n    p + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(hjust = 1))", { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50e138e6edecb53984014c3a" }, "created_at" : "2012-12-20T22:45:20Z", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/743", "labels" : [  ], "number" : 743, "body" : "\r\nExpressions in `aes()` are evaluated in the global environment,  but they should be evaluated in the calling environment. Example:\r\n\r\n```R\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\n\r\nfoo <- 4\r\nggplot(mtcars,  aes(x = wt + foo,  y = mpg)) +\r\n  geom_point()\r\n# Works\r\n\r\n\r\nf <- function() { \r\n  foo2 <- 4\r\n  ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x = wt + foo2,  y = mpg)) +\r\n    geom_point()\r\n }\r\n\r\nf()\r\n# Error in eval(expr,  envir,  enclos) : object 'foo2' not found\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt can be worked around by using `environment=environment()`:\r\n\r\n```R\r\ng <- function() { \r\n  foo3 <- 4\r\n  ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x = wt + foo3,  y = mpg), \r\n         environment = environment()) +\r\n    geom_point()\r\n }\r\n\r\ng()\r\n# Works\r\n```\r\n\r\nI think that should be the default behavior. @hadley,  is the current behavior a bug or a feature?\r\n\r\n\r\nThe problem is the definition of `ggplot.data.frame` in plot.r:\r\n\r\n```R\r\nggplot.data.frame <- function(data,  mapping=aes(),  ..., \r\n  environment = globalenv())\r\n```\r\n\r\nChanging it to use `parent.env()` fixes the problem:\r\n\r\n```R\r\nggplot.data.frame <- function(data,  mapping=aes(),  ..., \r\n  environment = parent.env())\r\n```\r\n", "milestone" : null, "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/743", "pull_request" : { "patch_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "closed_at" : null, "title" : "Wrong evaluation environment for expressions in aes()", "updated_at" : "2012-12-20T22:45:20Z", "user" : { "type" : "User", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "login" : "wch", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "id" : 86978, "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45" }, "events_url" : { "_id" : { "$oid" : "50ff2d4ebd3543a067008bcb" }, "milestone" : null, "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/756/events", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/756", "body" : "I posted this at SO and bring it here since it seems to be a real issue (and not just my confusion).  SO post: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14415073/inheritance-of-aesthetics-in-ggplot2-0-9-3-the-behavior-of-annotation-custom\r\n\r\nI looked at the code for annotation_custom and it has a hard-wired inherit.aes = TRUE which I think is the problem. I don't see why this function needs any aesthetic at all. I did try several ways to override it and set inherit.aes = FALSE but I was unable to fully penetrate the namespace and make it stick.\r\n\r\nHere is a MWE which illustrates the problem:\r\n\r\n````\r\nlibrary(\"ggplot2\")\r\nlibrary(\"grid\")\r\n\r\n# Case 1,  works as expected\r\n\r\ntd1 <- data.frame(x = rnorm(10),  y = rnorm(10))\r\n\r\ntf1 <- function(df) {  # works as expected\r\n\tp <- ggplot(aes(x = x,  y = y),  data = df)\r\n\tp <- p + geom_point(color = \"red\")\r\n\tp <- p + annotation_custom(circleGrob())\r\n\tprint(p)\r\n }\r\n\r\ntf1(td1)\r\n\r\n# Case 2,  no error,  but circle is not drawn\r\n\r\ntf2 <- function(df) {  # circle isn't draw,  but no error either\r\n\tp <- ggplot()\r\n\tp <- p + geom_point(data = df,  aes(x = x,  y = y),  color = \"red\")\t\t\r\n\tp <- p + annotation_custom(circleGrob())\r\n\tprint(p)\r\n\t }\r\n\r\ntf2(td1)\r\n\r\n# Case 3,  works if annotation is commented out\r\n\r\ntd3 <- data.frame(r = c(rnorm(5,  5,  1.5),  rnorm(5,  8,  2)), \r\n\tf1 = c(rep(\"L\",  5),  rep(\"H\",  5)),  f2 = rep(c(\"A\",  \"B\"),  5))\r\n\r\ntf3 <- function(df) { \r\n\tp <- ggplot()\r\n\tp <- p + geom_point(data = df,  \r\n\t\taes(x = f1,  y = r,  color = f2,  group = f2))\t\t\r\n#\tp <- p + annotation_custom(circleGrob()) # comment out and it works\r\n\tprint(p)\r\n\t }\r\n\r\ntf3(td3)\r\n````\r\n", "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "assignee" : null, "user" : { "type" : "User", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/events{ /privacy }", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/subscriptions", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson", "gravatar_id" : "abd9e2f10afa7b124129dfdb7e9baecf", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/received_events", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/abd9e2f10afa7b124129dfdb7e9baecf?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/orgs", "login" : "bryanhanson", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/repos", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/followers", "id" : 140350, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/bryanhanson/following" }, "state" : "open", "labels" : [  ], "title" : "aesthetic inheritance and annotation_custom", "number" : 756, "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/756/comments", "updated_at" : "2013-01-21T17:53:13Z", "comments" : 2, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/756", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/756/labels{ /name }", "closed_at" : null, "id" : 10141787, "created_at" : "2013-01-20T22:04:59Z", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50ff2d4ebd3543a067008bca" }, "milestone" : null, "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/757/events", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/757", "body" : "Currently,  the default values for the outlier arguments to geom_boxplot,  that control the shape,  colour and size of outliers,  cannot be changed with update_geom_defaults. It makes sense because technically these parameters are not aesthetics. On the other hand,  if the user changes,  say,  the default shape of geom_point,  the result will be that geom_point and geom_boxplot will produce points with different shapes,  which probably is not desirable or entirely expected.\r\n\r\nOne solution is to use the default values from geom_point as defaults for the outlier arguments in geom_boxplot,  so that\r\n\r\nupdate_geom_defaults(\"point\",  list(shape = 1,  colour='blue', size=4))\r\n\r\nalso affects the shape,  colour and size of the outlier points produced by geom_boxplot. Find patch attached.", "pull_request" : { "diff_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "assignee" : null, "user" : { "type" : "User", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/events{ /privacy }", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/subscriptions", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco", "gravatar_id" : "e780b272998a583d291a9897dc576132", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/received_events", "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e780b272998a583d291a9897dc576132?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/orgs", "login" : "nfdisco", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/repos", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/followers", "id" : 3323947, "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/nfdisco/following" }, "state" : "open", "labels" : [  ], "title" : "Use default aesthetics from geom_point as defaults for goem_boxplot outliers", "number" : 757, "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/757/comments", "updated_at" : "2013-01-21T00:42:55Z", "comments" : 1, "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/757", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/757/labels{ /name }", "closed_at" : null, "id" : 10143463, "created_at" : "2013-01-21T00:35:03Z", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "50ff2d4ebd3543a067008bc9" }, "milestone" : null, "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/758/events", "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/758", "body" : "Hi, \r\n\r\nI'm playing with the subset argument of `geom_*` and I'm finding that I end up with empty panels in the grid. I'm using version 0.9.3 of ggplot2.\r\n\r\nHere is my toy-example:\r\n```R\r\nd = data.frame(\r\n  x=ceiling(seq(1,  30) / 3),  y=runif(30), \r\n  group=as.factor(rep(c('A',  'B',  'C'),  10))\r\n)\r\n\r\nggplot(d,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  group=group,  color=group)) +\r\ngeom_point(subset=.(group != 'B')) +\r\nfacet_grid(group ~ .,  drop=TRUE)\r\n```\r\nNote: It makes no difference if group is a `factor` or not.\r\n\r\n![ image ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/878107/85606/0774e2a0-646d-11e2-8925-efc3db9c0adb.png)\r\n\r\nThe legend correctly omits B,  but the empty panel for B is still present.\r\n\r\nThe obvious workaround is to subset the data upfront,  e.g.\r\n```R\r\nggplot(subset(d,  group != 'B'),  aes(x=x,  y=y,  group=group,  color=group)) +\r\ngeom_point() +\r\nfacet_grid(group ~ .)\r\n```\r\nNote: If I set `drop=FALSE` in `facet_grid` in the workaround example,  then I end up with the same result as above.\r\n\r\nHowever,  it seems to me like the subset argument of `geom_*` could potentially take care of this. Thanks for providing this great tool!\r\n\r\nMinimal Examples:\r\n**R**:\r\n\r\n\toptions(OutDec = \", \")\r\n\trequire(ggplot2)\r\n\trequire(tikzDevice)\r\n\ttikz('example.tex', standAlone = TRUE,  width = 5, height = 5)\r\n\tqplot(1:4, 1:4, xlab=\"$\\\\pi$\");\r\n\tdev.off()\r\n\r\n**knitr**:\r\n\r\n\t\\documentclass{ artcl }\r\n\t\\begin{ document }\r\n\t\\begin{ figure }\r\n\t<<example, dev='tikz', cache=FALSE>>=\r\n\toptions(OutDec = \", \")\r\n\trequire(ggplot2)\r\n\tqplot(1:4, 1:4, xlab=\"$\\\\pi$\");\r\n\t@\r\n\t\\caption{ I need comma as decimal point.\\label{ fig:example } }\r\n\t\\end{ figure }\r\n\t\\end{ document }\r\n\r\nin either case the error is:\r\n\r\n\t(C:\\Users\\Jan\\AppData\\Roaming\\MiKTeX\\2.8\\tex\\generic\\pgf\\basiclayer\\pgfcoregraphic Fehler in getMetricsFromLatex(TeXMetrics) : \r\n\tTeX was unable to calculate metrics for the following string or character:\r\n\r\n\t1:4\r\n\t\r\n\tCommon reasons for failure include:\r\n\t  * The string contains a character which is special to LaTeX unless\r\n\t    escaped properly,  such as % or $.\r\n\t  * The string makes use of LaTeX commands provided by a package and\r\n\t    the tikzDevice was not told to load the package.\r\n\t\r\n\tThe contents of the LaTeX log of the aborted run have been printed above, \r\n\tit may contain additional details as to why the metric calculation failed.\r\n", "pull_request" : { "patch_url" : null, "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null }, "milestone" : null, "closed_at" : null, "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/760/events", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/760/comments", "state" : "open", "labels" : [  ], "title" : "Problem with Tikz and options(DecOut=', ')", "number" : 760, "id" : 10471432, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "512f9631bd3543e78d000180" }, "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/771", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/771/labels{ "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/771", "id" : 11510654, "number" : 771, "title" : "Fix polygon grouping bug", "user" : { "login" : "wch", "id" : 86978, "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "html_url" : "https://github.com/wch", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "type" : "User" }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 1, "created_at" : "2013-02-28T17:34:40Z", "updated_at" : "2013-02-28T17:38:43Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/771", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/771.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/771.patch" }, "body" : "Fixes #741 and fixes #749.\r\n\r\nThe problem is that the `group` returned from `coord_munch` is sometimes a character vector,  and it was passed to `polygonGrob` as the `id` value. But `id` must be a numeric vector,  according to the help page:\r\n\r\n> id: A numeric vector used to separate locations in ‘x’ and ‘y’ into multiple polygons.  All locations with the same ‘id’ belong to the same polygon.\r\n\r\nConverting it to a factor ensures that it's numeric. I had to use `mode()` because this is one of those times where `is.numeric` is reporting something other than what's desired. What's needed is something that will report TRUE for factors,  integers,  and floats,  and FALSE for strings. `mode()` is the function that does the trick\r\n\r\n\r\n```R\r\nchar  <- \"A\"\r\nfac   <- factor(\"A\")\r\nint   <- 1L\r\nfloat <- 1.1\r\n\r\ntypeof(char)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"character\"\r\nstorage.mode(char)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"character\"\r\nmode(char)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"character\"\r\nis.numeric(char)\r\n# [ 1 ] FALSE\r\nis.integer(char)\r\n# [ 1 ] FALSE\r\n\r\ntypeof(fac)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"integer\"\r\nstorage.mode(fac)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"integer\"\r\nmode(fac)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"numeric\"\r\nis.numeric(fac)\r\n# [ 1 ] FALSE\r\nis.integer(fac)\r\n# [ 1 ] FALSE\r\n\r\ntypeof(int)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"integer\"\r\nstorage.mode(int)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"integer\"\r\nmode(int)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"numeric\"\r\nis.numeric(int)\r\n# [ 1 ] TRUE\r\nis.integer(int)\r\n# [ 1 ] TRUE\r\n\r\ntypeof(float)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"double\"\r\nstorage.mode(float)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"double\"\r\nmode(float)\r\n# [ 1 ] \"numeric\"\r\nis.numeric(float)\r\n# [ 1 ] TRUE\r\nis.integer(float)\r\n# [ 1 ] FALSE\r\n```", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "51343a7abd354360a700001a" }, "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/772", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/772/labels{ /name }", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/772/comments", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/772/events", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/772", "id" : 11519125, "number" : 772, "title" : "Fix logticks color (#767)", "user" : { "login" : "wch", "id" : 86978, "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "gravatar_id" : "3984cd736dbbb0a76fcdb7c5aa087f45", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch", "html_url" : "https://github.com/wch", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/followers", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/following", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/subscriptions", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/orgs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/events{ /privacy }", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/wch/received_events", "type" : "User" }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "closed", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2013-02-28T21:01:50Z", "updated_at" : "2013-03-01T03:17:52Z", "closed_at" : "2013-03-01T03:17:52Z", "pull_request" : { "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/772", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/772.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/772.patch" }, "body" : "This fixes #767. I adapted some of the code from `annotate`. I'm not sure this is the cleanest way to do it,  but it works.\r\n\r\nExamples:\r\n\r\n```r\r\ndf <- data.frame(x=1,  y=c(1, 10, 100, 1000),  z=c('a', 'b', 'a', 'b'))\r\np <- ggplot(df,  aes(x=x,  y=y,  colour=z))+\r\n  geom_point() +\r\n  scale_y_log10() +\r\n  scale_color_manual(values=c(\"red\",  \"black\"))\r\n\r\np + annotation_logticks(sides=\"lrtb\")\r\n\r\np + annotation_logticks(sides=\"lrtb\",  alpha = .3,  colour = \"red\")\r\n\r\np + annotation_logticks(sides=\"lrtb\",  alpha = .3,  color = \"red\")\r\n\r\n```", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

scale_x_discrete()\r\n```\r\ngives\r\n\r\n```\r\nError: Discrete value supplied to continuous scale\r\n```\r\nThe error is incorrect: the problem is that a Date was passed to a discrete scale,  not "created_at" : "2013-03-21T17:08:03Z", "updated_at" : "2013-03-21T17:08:03Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/784", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/784.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/784.patch" }, "body" : "```stat_ecdf``` fails when at least one value in ```data$x``` is ```NA``` or ```Inf```:\r\n- for ```NA```,  the ```min```/```max``` become ```NA```,  leading to an error in ```seq```\r\n- for ```Inf``` the min/max become infinite,  and the finite end of the range is the only finite point in the result of the ```seq```-call. \r\n\r\nThe fix removes ```NA``` and ```Inf``` for the purpose of computing the x-range. Note that all values are still included in the call to ```ecdf``` (which removes NAs,  but handles ```Inf```s correctly).", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

stackoverflow ](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3541713/how-to-plot-two-histograms-together-in-r):\r\n\r\n````\r\nchicks <- data.frame(length = rnorm(100,  4,  2),  animal = 2)\r\ncarrots <- data.frame(length = rnorm(500,  9,  3),  animal = 1)\r\n\r\nmeasured_things <- rbind(chicks,  carrots)\r\n\r\nggplot(measured_things,  aes(x=length,  fill=animal)) + geom_bar()\r\n````\r\n\r\nWhich produces the flabbergasting error message:\r\n\r\n> Error in unit(tic_pos.c,  \"mm\") : 'x' and 'units' must have length > 0\r\n\r\n````\r\nmeasured_things$status = c('animal',  'not')[ measured_things$animal ]\r\n# or measured_things$status = as.factor(measured_things$animal)\r\n\r\nggplot(measured_things,  aes(x=length,  fill=status)) + geom_bar()\r\n````\r\n\r\nWhich works beautifully! Seems like `aes(fill=...)` and `aes(colour=...)` could very well force conversion to factor,  but there might be other use-cases I'm not aware of,  but at least the error message could be more helpful.\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

I am using two geom_bars with subsets of original dataset (variable g with two levels 'A' and 'B').\r\n\r\nHow can I preserve original order of factor variable? There is no problem when my var is numeric,  but let assume that x should be factor.\r\n\r\nHere is my code:\r\n\r\n```{ r }\r\ndane<-data.frame(x=1:10, y=seq(-5, 4), g=rep(c('A', 'B'), each=5))\r\ndane$x<-as.factor(dane$x)\r\n\r\n  ggplot(data=dane, aes(x=x, y=y, fill=g)) + \r\n    geom_bar(subset=.(g=='A'), stat='identity') +\r\n    geom_bar(subset=.(g=='B'), stat='identity')\r\n````\r\n\r\nand a result\r\n\r\n![ wrong_order ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/3464669/300341/d93f4764-9594-11e2-9b93-8e8ebf5559c0.jpeg)\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "Call this file `dat.csv`.\r\n\r\n\"x\", \"y\"\r\n0.1, 0.9\r\n0.2, 0.8\r\n0.3, 0.8\r\n0.3, 0.8\r\n0.4, 0.7\r\n0.5, 0.8\r\n0.6, 0.8\r\n0.7, 0.8\r\n0.8, 0.75\r\n0.8, 0.76\r\n0.9, 0.8\r\n1.0, 0.7\r\n\r\nThen\r\n\r\n    #!/usr/bin/Rscript\r\n    library(ggplot2)\r\n    stat = read.csv(\"dat.csv\")\r\n    png(file = \"graph.png\")\r\n    stat = ggplot() + geom_area(data=stat,  aes(x,  y))\r\n    print(stat)\r\n    dev.off()\r\n\r\ngives a plot that is a little curious. See displayed graph. The\r\nproblem is that the x value 0.3 is duplicated. This might be\r\nconsidered an error,  but could be handled more\r\ngracefully. Additionally,  I would like to make a plea for points like\r\n(0.8, 0.75) and (0.8, 0.76) to be dealt with in a reasonable way. Such\r\nvalues can easily be produced as a result of rounding errors or\r\nsimulations that are not using enough precision. I suspect that\r\nwhatever geom_area would do with (0.8, 0.75) & (0.8, 0.76) is masked by\r\nthe duplicate x value problem.\r\n\r\nTested on Debian squeeze with R 2.15.3 and 0.9.3.1.\r\n\r\n![ graph ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2557767/349008/65b80dde-9f9f-11e2-8e53-48af90d6b1a2.png)", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "This isn't an issue,  this is more of a question about the paradigm being created for overall theme management. \r\n\r\nIt would be nice if one could wrap geom and scale defaults in theme definitions. As it is now,  one can define a theme for most attributes associated with the plot. \r\n\r\n```\r\ntheme_example <- function(base_size = 12) {  \r\n   structure(list(\r\n      ...\r\n   ),  class=c(\"theme\", \"gg\"),  complete=TRUE/FALSE)\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\nHowever,  defaults for scale and geom are instantiated seperately. \r\n\r\n```\r\nupdate_geom_defaults(\"geom\",  list(...))\r\nscale_colour_discrete <- function(...) scale_colour_brewer(...,  palette=\"Dark2\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis instantiation forces the user to remember to add the theme elements,  and forces the user to repeat themselves by writing out the defaults over and over for each use case (think reporting via knitr). \r\n\r\nPerhaps there's a better way to manage this process that I'm not seeing? \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"created_at" : "2013-04-22T21:17:10Z", "updated_at" : "2013-04-22T21:17:10Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "The `nrow` and `ncol` arguments to `facet_wrap` only make sense as positive integers,  but `ggplot2` curerntly does not check their values when the plot variable is assigned.  For example\r\n\r\n    p1 <- ggplot(CO2,  aes(conc,  uptake)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~ Type,  nrow = 0)\r\n\r\nis allowed,  an even\r\n\r\n    p2 <- ggplot(CO2,  aes(conc,  uptake)) + geom_point() + facet_wrap(~ Type,  nrow = -2)\r\n\r\nIt is only when these plots come to be printed that the problem manifests.\r\n\r\nI suggest adding a check that `nrow` and `ncol` are positive integers into the `facet_wrap` function.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

this is a problem with faceting,  it is a problem with the way `qplot` builds the data from the environment if you don't pass it as a parameter. \r\nx <- c(0,  0,  1,  1)\r\ny <- c(0,  1,  0,  1)\r\nf1 <- c(\"a\",  \"a\",  \"b\",  \"b\")\r\nf2 <- c(\"c\",  \"d\",  \"c\",  \"d\")\r\nF1 <- factor(f1)\r\nF2 <- factor(f2)\r\nF11 <- factor(f1,  levels = c(\"b\",  \"a\"))\r\nF22 <- factor(f2,  levels = c(\"d\",  \"c\"))\r\n\r\ndf <- data.frame(x,  y,  F1,  F2,  F11,  F22)\r\n\r\nqplot(x,  y,  facets = F1 ~ F2) # correct\r\nggplot(df,  aes(x,  y)) + geom_point(color = \"red\",  size = 4) + facet_grid(F1 ~ F2) # correct\r\nqplot(x,  y,  facets = F11 ~ F22) # wrong\r\nggplot(df,  aes(x,  y)) + geom_point(color = \"blue\",  size = 4) + facet_grid(F11 ~ F22) # correct\r\nqplot(x,  y,  facets = F11 ~ F22,  data = df) # correct\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

following code, \r\n\r\n```\r\nb = data.frame(energy = rep(c(1, 2), 5),  \r\n               R = rep(c(1-1e-10,  1),  each=5),  \r\n               N = c(55,  55,  65,  65,  75,  75,  85,  85,  95, because the z data is practically constant across the panel,  and showing a level line suggests that there is some variation commensurate with the chosen binwidth. /name }", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/817/comments", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/817/events", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/817", "id" : 15341973, "number" : 817, "title" : "multiple calls to annotation_custom fail in certain cases", "user" : { "login" : "fmitha", "id" : 2557767, "avatar_url" : "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2b37134235e21817f74cd8c47eb0538d?d=https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com%2Fimages%2Fgravatars%2Fgravatar-user-420.png", "gravatar_id" : "https://api.github.com/users/fmitha/received_events", "type" : "User" }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2013-06-10T11:24:25Z", "updated_at" : "2013-06-10T11:24:25Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "I'm copying the example from Sandy Musgrove in\r\nhttp://stackoverflow.com/a/13327793/350713\r\n\r\nIn the following code,  two calls to `annotation_custom` result in the object `plotNew`.\r\nBut the two legends that should show up in that plot don't,  \r\n(We can call up the display by simply typing `plotNew`.)\r\nOnly the first added shows up,  namely `leg2`.\r\nHowever,  in the case of `plotNew2`,  both circles added via `annotation_custom` show up.\r\n\r\n```\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\nlibrary(gridExtra)\r\nlibrary(gtable)\r\n\r\n##Some data\r\ndf <- data.frame(\r\n  x = 1:10, \r\n  y = 1:10, \r\n  colour = factor(sample(1:3,  10,  replace = TRUE)), \r\n  size = factor(sample(1:3,  10,  replace = TRUE)))\r\n\r\n### Step 1\r\n# Draw a plot with the colour legend\r\n(p1 <- ggplot(data = df,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) +\r\n   geom_point(aes(colour = colour)) +\r\n   theme_bw() +\r\n   theme(legend.position = \"top\"))\r\n\r\n## Extract the colour legend - leg1\r\nleg1 <- gtable_filter(ggplot_gtable(ggplot_build(p1)),  \"guide-box\") \r\n\r\n## Step 2\r\n## Draw a plot with the size legend\r\n(p2 <- ggplot(data = df,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) +\r\n   geom_point(aes(size = size)) +\r\n   theme_bw())\r\n\r\n## Extract the size legend - leg2\r\nleg2 <- gtable_filter(ggplot_gtable(ggplot_build(p2)),  \"guide-box\") \r\n\r\n## Step 3\r\n## Draw a plot with no legends - plot\r\n(plot <- ggplot(data = df,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) +\r\n   geom_point(aes(size = size,  colour = colour)) +\r\n   theme_bw() +\r\n   theme(legend.position = \"none\"))\r\n\r\nplotNew <- plot + \r\n  annotation_custom(grob = leg2,  xmin = 7,  xmax = 10,  ymin = 0,  ymax = 4) +\r\n  annotation_custom(grob = leg1,  xmin = 2.5,  xmax = 5,  ymin = 7.5,  ymax = 10)\r\n\r\nplotNew2 <- plot +\r\n  annotation_custom(circleGrob()) + annotation_custom(circleGrob(x=0.2,  y=0.2,  r=0.2))\r\n```", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

The following code creates such a data frame and plots\r\nthe data:\r\n\r\n```\r\nrequire(ggplot2)\r\nrequire(scales)\r\nrequire(lubridate)\r\ntimelist <- ymd_hm(c(\"2013-05-01 12:00\", \"2013-05-02 18:00\", \"2013-05-03 06:00\"), tz=\"America/Los_Angeles\")\r\nsampleDF <- data.frame(time = timelist,  values = c(3, 4, 2))\r\nqplot(time,  values,  data = sampleDF)+scale_x_datetime(minor_breaks=date_breaks(\"6 hour\"))\r\n```\r\n\r\nWhen I run the code above,  I get a plot with the three points at the\r\nright times,  but the minor break lines are offset apparently by 3 hours\r\nfrom the axis.  I expected the minor breaks to coincide with the major\r\nbreaks.  That is,  I expected minor breaks at 0:00,  6:00,  12:00,  18:00, \r\n...,  with major breaks as scales chose,  but I get minor breaks at 3:00, \r\n9:00,  ....\r\n\r\nMy time zone is \"America/Los_Angeles\",  but I get the same result when I\r\nuse \"UTC\" for the data instead.  \r\n\r\nThere was a discussion about this at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/ggplot2/Kvdx70hF51A.  While Brian Waismeyer's solution seems to work,  it seems more than a bit unintuitive and thus out of character for ggplot2 and a bit fidgety.  \r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

set below,  thing1 is numeric,  and thing2 is a factor (but otherwise identical to thing1). For simplicity,  the summary function is just the max value in the bin. When the z element is a factor,  the hexagons overlap. \r\n\r\n    library(ggplot2)\r\n    library(hexbin)\r\n    DF=data.frame(xpos=rnorm(1000), \r\n                  ypos=rnorm(1000), \r\n                  thing1=rep(1:9, length.out=100), \r\n                  thing2=as.factor(rep(1:9, length.out=100)))\r\n    ggplot(DF,  aes(x=xpos,  y=ypos,  z=thing1)) +  \r\n      stat_summary_hex(fun=function(x){ x[ which.max(x) ] })\r\n    ggplot(DF,  aes(x=xpos,  y=ypos,  z=thing2)) +  \r\n      stat_summary_hex(fun=function(x){ x[ which.max(x) ] })\r\n\r\n![ thing1 ][ 1 ]\r\n![ thing2 ][ 2 ]\r\n\r\nThis also occurs with `ggplot(DF,  aes(x=xpos,  y=ypos,  z=thing2)) + stat_binhex()`.\r\n\r\nThis is [ cross posted ][ 3 ] on stackoverflow.com.\r\n\r\n  [ 1 ]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/lbZzU.png\r\n  [ 2 ]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/CV8BN.png\r\n  [ 3 ]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17373751/in-stat-summary-hex-why-do-hexagons-overlap-if-z-is-a-factor", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"2013-06-29T00:30:46Z", "updated_at" : "2013-06-29T00:30:46Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "Example follows of the bug that occurs when overplotting qmap with a SpatialPolygons* object that extend beyond the zoom limit of the map. \r\n\r\nI think the same issue was noted last year in stack overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13469566/polygons-nicely-cropping-ggplot2-ggmap-at-different-zoom-levels \r\n\r\nI'm wondering if a built-in fix is in the pipeline?\r\n\r\n```\r\n# reproducible example of issue when overplotting qmap with a\r\n# SpatialPolygons* object that extends beyond the edge of the map \r\n\r\nlibrary(ggmap)\r\nlibrary(grid)\r\nlibrary(sp)\r\n\r\n# function to create a SpatialPointsDataFrame (with dummy data)\r\n# that represents a single box polygon centered around 'coordinate', \r\n# with box sides of length 'size'\r\npt2box <- function(coordinate,  size) { \r\n    lowerleft <- coordinate-(size/2)\r\n    coords <- rbind(\r\n        lowerleft, \r\n        lowerleft + c(0,  size), \r\n        lowerleft + size, \r\n        lowerleft + c(size,  0), \r\n        lowerleft\r\n    )\r\n    SpatialPolygonsDataFrame(\r\n        SpatialPolygons(list(\r\n            Polygons(list(\r\n                Polygon(coords)\r\n            ),  1)\r\n        )\r\n    ),  data.frame(x=1))\r\n }\r\n\r\n# grab Google map of the region around Baylor University\r\nbaylor <- qmap(\"baylor university\",  zoom=8)\r\n\r\n# lat/lon for city of austin\r\naustin <- c(-97.7428,  30.2669)\r\n\r\n# this works -- box fits on plot\r\nbaylor + geom_polygon(aes(x=long,  y=lat),  fill=NA,  colour=\"black\", \r\n    data=pt2box(austin,  0.4))\r\n# this doesn't -- box doesn't fit on plot\r\nbaylor + geom_polygon(aes(x=long,  y=lat),  fill=NA,  colour=\"black\", \r\n    data=pt2box(austin,  0.5))\r\n```", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

facet with a variable named `ROW` or `COL` results in a cryptic error.\r\n\r\n```r-lang\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  ROW=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~ROW)\r\n```\r\ngives\r\n```\r\nError in scale_apply(layer_data,  x_vars,  scale_train,  SCALE_X,  panel$x_scales) : \r\n  \r\n```\r\n\r\nThe problem is that the `panels` data.frame contains two instances of `ROW` and when the `PANEL` column is added to `data`,  it get the wrong one at https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/blob/master/R/facet-locate.r#L76. \r\n\r\nThe problem is not limited to `ROW`. The same (or the same with additional warnings) error happens for any variable which has the same name as one of the internal `panels` columns:\r\n\r\n```r-lang\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  ROW=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~ROW)\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  COL=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~COL)\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  PANEL=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~PANEL)\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  SCALE_X=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~SCALE_X)\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  SCALE_Y=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~SCALE_Y)\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  AXIS_X=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~AXIS_X)\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  AXIS_Y=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_wrap(~AXIS_Y)\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt also is not limited to `facet_wrap`; `facet_grid` has the same issues:\r\n\r\n```r-lang\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  ROW=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_grid(~ROW)\r\nggplot(data=transform(mtcars,  ROW=am),  aes(wt,  mpg)) +\r\n  geom_blank() +\r\n  facet_grid(ROW~.)\r\n```", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"2013-07-29T07:37:52Z", "updated_at" : "2013-07-29T07:37:52Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/844", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/844.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/844.patch" }, "body" : "The current behavior of theme_bw() takes the same panel.margin=unit(0.25, \"lines\") as theme_grey(). This setting makes sense for theme_grey() since you need white space as a border to distinguish the different panels. However,  theme_bw() uses a grey line for the panel border,  yielding the white space un-necessary. In fact,  as shown below on page 63 of Envisioning Information by Edward Tufte,  the \"grid boxes\" or space between panels,  are a bad design (top). A better design is grey boxes around each panel with no white space between them (bottom).\r\n\r\n![ thick-facets-are-bad ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/932850/870117/ce885c36-f820-11e2-9852-7719686c54a1.png)\r\n\r\nOn the left: the current default output when using theme_bw() in ggplot2. On the right: the same plot with theme_bw() after applying my patch,  which changes only one line of code.\r\n\r\n![ space-nospace ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/932850/870110/7068ffac-f820-11e2-894c-e8440d87c151.png)\r\n\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"2013-08-10T17:59:05Z", "updated_at" : "2013-08-10T17:59:05Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "I created [ a full example on StackOverflow ](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18157975/combine-geom-tile-and-facet-grid-facet-wrap-and-remove-space-between-tiles-gg/18164691#18164691) demonstrating my experience (the answer (user name *Hendy*) I posted contains it).\r\n\r\nThe gist:\r\n\r\n- I created a linear model with `fit <- lm(x ~ y,  ...)` with four inputs (`x`s) and one response\r\n- I created a new set of data to generated a facetted tile plot of each combination of two `x`s vs. response (`fill = z`) over a range of values,  holding the other two variables not pictured in each tile plot at constant values when using `predict()` to generate the data set. This was done with `lapply` and `expand.grid`.\r\n- I used the following to create my tile plot:\r\n\r\n```\r\nhead(plot_data)\r\n           x y var1 var2     resp\r\n1 -3.0000000 0   x1   x2 69.05287\r\n2 -2.3333333 0   x1   x2 70.37217\r\n3 -1.6666667 0   x1   x2 71.69147\r\n\r\ntail(plot_data)\r\n           x y var1 var2      resp\r\n595 11.66667 7   x3   x4  92.37510\r\n596 13.33333 7   x3   x4  99.02534\r\n597 15.00000 7   x3   x4 105.67558\r\n```\r\n\r\nMy ggplot call was like so\r\n\r\n```\r\np <- ggplot(plot_data,  aes(x = x,  y = y)) + geom_tile(aes(fill = resp))\r\np <- p + facet_wrap(var2 ~ var1,  scales = \"free\",  ncol = 3)\r\n```\r\nI got a blank plot as a result.\r\n\r\n![ blank plot ](http://i.stack.imgur.com/zqcQD.png)\r\n\r\nIf I round `plot_data$x` and `plot_data$y`,  it works (though I also ended up having to create `height` and `width` values using `ddply` for each unique combination of `var1` and `var2` in order to get the tiles to fill the space... but that's a separate issue):\r\n\r\n```\r\nplot_data_round <- plot_data\r\nplot_data_round[ ,  c(\"x\",  \"y\") ] <- round(plot_data_round[ ,  c(\"x\",  \"y\") ],  5)\r\n\r\n# same plot call as above\r\np <- ggplot(plot_data_round,  aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = resp))\r\np <- p + geom_tile(aes(fill = resp))\r\np <- p + facet_wrap(var2 ~ var1,  scales = \"free\",  ncol = 3) + theme_bw()\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot fills in some tiles ](http://i.stack.imgur.com/YBKZi.png)\r\n\r\nWhy would the output of my `expand.grid` call not create a plot,  but rounding those vectors would?\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nP.S. If you need the full code here,  I am happy to provide it. Since I already copied it elsewhere,  I figured linking to the SO post would be sufficient.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "How to reproduce:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(data.table)\r\nlibrary(lubridate)\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\n\r\n# Prepare some random data\r\nset.seed(1234)\r\ndt <- data.table(x = rnorm(365*5),  d = seq(ymd(20130101),  ymd(20131231),  by = 86400))\r\ndt.m <- dt[ ,  list(total = sum(x)),  by = list(month = floor_date(d,  \"month\")) ]\r\n# Create a basic scatterplot chart\r\np <- qplot(month,  total,  data = dt.m)\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis works:\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# Both of these work as expected and produce the same result\r\np + geom_segment(x = as.numeric(ymd(20130401)),  xend = as.numeric(ymd(20130701)),  \r\n  y = -10,  yend = 10)\r\np + geom_segment(aes(x = ymd(20130401),  xend = ymd(20130701),  \r\n  y = -10,  yend = 10))\r\n```\r\n\r\nbut this doesn't:\r\n\r\n```r\r\n> p + annotate(\"segment\",  x = as.numeric(ymd(20130401)),  xend = as.numeric(ymd(20130701)),  \r\n  y = -10,  yend = 10)\r\nError: Invalid input: time_trans works with objects of class POSIXct only\r\n\r\n> p + annotate(\"segment\",  x = ymd(20130401),  xend = ymd(20130701),  \r\n  y = -10,  yend = 10)\r\nError in Ops.POSIXt((x - from[ 1 ]),  diff(from)) : \r\n  '/' not defined for \"POSIXt\" objects \r\n\r\n> p + annotate(\"segment\",  aes(x = ymd(20130401),  xend = ymd(20130701),  \r\n  y = -10,  yend = 10))\r\nError in as.data.frame.default(x[ [ i ] ],  optional = TRUE,  stringsAsFactors = stringsAsFactors) : \r\n  cannot coerce class \"\"uneval\"\" to a data.frame\r\n```\r\n\r\nI have also posted a question to SO - documentation for stat_bin ](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/stat_bin.html):\r\n\r\n    simple <- data.frame(x = rep(1:10,  each = 2))\r\n    base <- ggplot(simple,  aes(x))\r\n    # By default,  right = TRUE,  and intervals are of the form (a,  b ]\r\n    base + stat_bin(binwidth = 1,  drop = FALSE,  right = TRUE,  col = \"black\")\r\n\r\nBut try this out:\r\n\r\n    simple <- data.frame(x = rep(1:10,  each = 2))\r\n    ggplot(simple,  aes(x)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 1,  col = \"black\")\r\n\r\n![ 2013-09-29_182806 ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/379357/1234155/d03f1730-295e-11e3-804c-55daf479554d.png)\r\n\r\n    ggplot(simple,  aes(x)) + geom_histogram(right = F,  binwidth = 1,  col = \"black\")\r\n\r\n![ 2013-09-29_182806 ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/379357/1234155/d03f1730-295e-11e3-804c-55daf479554d.png)\r\n\r\n    ggplot(simple,  aes(x)) + geom_histogram(right = T,  binwidth = 1,  col = \"black\")\r\n\r\n![ 2013-09-29_182927 ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/379357/1234157/fffc6068-295e-11e3-84c6-bb938b1047d8.png)\r\n\r\nSo... no option is the same as explicitly setting `right = F`,  and `right = T` obviously looks different than the other two. The argument summary at the top of the page actually has it right,  but I was looking at the example to get more clarification on what it did -- caused me quite a lot of confusion lately!", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "This may be by design,  but if limits are set on a scale,  values above the limit value are assigned a lower value,  causing potential erroneous interpretation.  I would recommend flooring values above limits to the highest value within limits.\r\n\r\n    test <- data.frame(x=c(\"A\", \"B\", \"C\"), y=c(\"B\", \"B\", \"B\"),  value=c(0, 1, 2))\r\n    qplot(data=test,  x=x, y=y, fill=value, geom=\"tile\")+scale_fill_gradient(low=\"white\",  high=\"black\",  limits=c(0,  1))\r\n\r\n![ rplot ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/806435/1351626/f3ee4150-3729-11e3-9eef-ce6b98c5cbc5.jpeg)\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

Did I miss something ? \r\n\r\nJean-Marc", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"2013-10-24T21:52:46Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/868", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/868.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/868.patch" }, "body" : "Added an option to create boxplots of widths proportional to the square-roots of the number of observations they represent. It resembles the 'varwidth' parameter to graphics::boxplot. \r\n\r\nNote that the implementation poses slight overhead to calculate_groups() in Stat,  as I compute the maximum group size there.\r\n\r\nI tested the implementation extensively. It seems to work well with all geom_boxplot examples as well as when creating boxplots implicitly using stat_boxplot.\r\n\r\nNote that using varwidth=TRUE results in warnings of 'position_dodge requires constant width: output may be incorrect'. This poses a real problem (only) in the case of breaking groups further by another factor as e.g. in \r\n```\r\np <- ggplot(mtcars,  aes(factor(cyl),  mpg))\r\np + geom_boxplot(aes(fill = factor(vs)), varwidth=TRUE)\r\n```\r\nwhere boxplots in single group are not put side by side,  but on top of each other,  in contrast to the case of not using varwidth:\r\n```\r\np <- ggplot(mtcars,  aes(factor(cyl),  mpg))\r\np + geom_boxplot(aes(fill = factor(vs)))\r\n```\r\nHowever,  IMHO this is not a big deal.\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"https://api.github.com/users/dougmitarotonda/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2013-10-28T16:33:56Z", "updated_at" : "2013-10-28T16:33:56Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "The spacing around the borders of ggplots depend on whether you are using `ylim` or `coord_cartesian`. If you are plotting a single plot,  this difference is negligible. However,  when faceting plots,  the differences become noticeable because the labels overlap each other. \r\n\r\nI understand the difference in subsetting vs. zooming using `ylim` vs. `coord_cartesian`,  respectively,  but at the end of the day all you are doing in either case is changing the range of an axis. I think you should expect the same plot output regardless of whether you are subsetting or zooming. \r\n\r\nCurrently,  `coord_cartesian` causes the labels to overlap,  while `ylim` looks ok.\r\n\r\nFor example, \r\n```\r\nlibrary(ggplot2) \r\n# Data to plot\r\ndf <- data.frame(A = 1:6,  B = 1:6,  F = rep(c(\"H\",  \"L\"),  times = 3))\r\n# Default case. The axis labels for the H and L facets 2 and 6,  respectively,  do not overlap.\r\np <- ggplot(df,  aes(x = A,  y = B)) + geom_point() + facet_grid(F ~ .)\r\n# Using ylim,  things continue to look good. There is a bit of spacing below the 0 in H and 5 and L \r\n# so that they don't overlap.\r\np + ylim(0,  5)\r\n# But I don't want to subset the data,  I want to zoom in. In this example it does not matter,  but \r\n# my real data is much different. To do this I need to use coord_cartesian...\r\np + coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0,  5))\r\n# As you can see,  none of that nice spacing between the values and the border exist anymore so the 0 and 5 \r\n# sit directly on top of each other. \r\n# The best solution has been to edit the panel margins directly\r\np + coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0,  5)) + theme(panel.margin = grid::unit(0.6,  \"cm\"))\r\n# But this still does not have the same,  \"nice\" spacing that of neither the default \r\n# plots nor the subsetted ylim plots.\r\n``` ", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2013-11-05T08:39:57Z", "updated_at" : "2013-11-05T08:39:57Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "Automatic setting of breaks fails with probit scale if there are values\r\ntoo close to 0 or 1.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBug\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nqplot(c(0.25,  8),  c(0.03,  0.95),  data = soilSample) + scale_y_continuous(trans = \"probit\")\r\n```\r\n\r\n```\r\n## Error: 'from' cannot be NA,  NaN or infinite\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nData-dependent: y values further away from 0 or 1 don't trigger it\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nqplot(c(0.25,  8),  c(0.3,  0.7),  data = soilSample) + scale_y_continuous(trans = \"probit\")\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-3 ](http://i.imgur.com/fF3Hcu5.png) \r\n\r\n\r\nWorkaround: Set explicit breaks\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nqplot(c(0.25,  8),  c(0.03,  0.95),  data = soilSample) + scale_y_continuous(trans = \"probit\",  \r\n    breaks = seq(0.2,  0.8,  0.2))\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-4 ](http://i.imgur.com/3aFoe1r.png) \r\n\r\n\r\nBug with explicit breaks\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nqplot(c(0.25,  8),  c(0.03,  0.95),  data = soilSample) + scale_y_continuous(trans = \"probit\",  \r\n    breaks = seq(0,  1,  0.2))\r\n```\r\n\r\n```\r\n## Error: 'from' cannot be NA,  NaN or infinite\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nSee also https://github.com/yihui/tikzDevice/commit/9f381e693d857c468921d892641f0387761f9078\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
