"2013-11-22T12:44:04Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "When plotting the boxplot of a Date variable,  by default,  the limits of the axis seem to be set as the limits of the whiskers which prevents the outliers to be shown.\r\n\r\n\r\nExample and output:\r\n\r\nrequire(ggplot2)\r\np_date <- ggplot(df,  aes(x = fact,  y = as.Date(date))) +\r\n  geom_boxplot() +\r\n  labs(title = \"class: Date\\n(outliers not shown)\")\r\np_numeric <- ggplot(df,  aes(x = fact,  y = as.numeric(date))) +\r\n  geom_boxplot() +\r\n  labs(title = \" class: numeric\\n(outliers shown as expected)\")\r\np_integer <- ggplot(df,  aes(x = fact,  y = as.integer(date))) +\r\n  geom_boxplot() +\r\n  labs(title = \" class: integer\\n(outliers shown as expected)\")\r\np_date_limits <- ggplot(df,  aes(x = fact,  y = as.Date(date))) +\r\n  geom_boxplot() +\r\n  scale_y_date(limits = c(min(df$date),  max(df$date))) +\r\n  labs(title = \"class: Date. Scale limits adjusted.\\n(outliers shown as expected)\")\r\nrequire(gridExtra)\r\ngrid.arrange(p_date,  p_integer,  p_numeric,  p_date_limits,  nrow = 2,  ncol = 2)\r\n\r\n![ ggplot2_bug_report_example ](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/5382593/1600554/45f342a6-5373-11e3-8781-4fe9f5fd7e9a.png)\r\n\r\n\r\nR session information\r\n\r\nR version 3.0.1 (2013-05-16)\r\nPlatform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64 (64-bit)\r\n\r\nlocale:\r\n[ 1 ] LC_COLLATE=Swedish_Sweden.1252  LC_CTYPE=Swedish_Sweden.1252    LC_MONETARY=Swedish_Sweden.1252 LC_NUMERIC=C                   \r\n[ 5 ] LC_TIME=Swedish_Sweden.1252    \r\n\r\nattached base packages:\r\n[ 1 ] grid      stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n\r\nother attached packages:\r\n[ 1 ] gridExtra_0.9.1 ggplot2_0.9.3.1\r\n\r\nloaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n[ 1 ] colorspace_1.2-3   dichromat_2.0-0    digest_0.6.3       gtable_0.1.2       labeling_0.2       MASS_7.3-26        munsell_0.4.2     \r\n [ 8 ] plyr_1.8           proto_0.3-10       RColorBrewer_1.0-5 reshape2_1.2.2     scales_0.2.3       stringr_0.6.2      tools_3.0.1 \r\n\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

I have shown an example before and after applying this change.\r\n\r\n# Before\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEverything looks good by default\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\n```\r\n\r\n```\r\n## Loading required package: methods\r\n```\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(grid)\r\n\r\n(p <- qplot(diamonds$cut,  binwidth=0.5) + theme_bw(24) +\r\n   theme(axis.text.x=element_text(vjust=0.5)))\r\nshowViewport()\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-2 ](http://i.imgur.com/wJvs0Zw.png) \r\n\r\n\r\nNow play with the the other extreme:\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\n(p1 <- p + theme(axis.title=element_text(vjust=1)))\r\nshowViewport()\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-4 ](http://i.imgur.com/GU9x5al.png) ](http://i.imgur.com/DkidGOH.png) \r\n\r\n\r\nTop-down,  `vjust==1`:\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\np1 + theme(axis.title.x=element_text(angle=180),  axis.title.y=element_text(angle=270))\r\nshowViewport()\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-6 ](http://i.imgur.com/4zvJ5q3.png) \r\n\r\n\r\nThis is inconsistent.\r\n\r\n# After\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEverything looks good by default\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\n```\r\n\r\n```\r\n## Loading required package: methods\r\n```\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(grid)\r\n\r\n(p <- qplot(diamonds$cut,  binwidth=0.5) + theme_bw(24) +\r\n   theme(axis.text.x=element_text(vjust=0.5)))\r\nshowViewport()\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot theme(axis.title=element_text(vjust=0)))\r\nshowViewport()\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ plot of chunk unnamed-chunk-3 ](http://i.imgur.com/1iy0nOP.png) \r\n\r\n\r\nAnd the other extreme:\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\n(p1 <- annotation lines:\r\n```R\r\nggplot( data.frame( x = rlnorm( 100,  -4 ),  y = rlnorm( 100,  -4 ) ), \r\n        aes( x = x,  y = y ) ) +\r\n    geom_point() +\r\n    annotate( 'segment',  x = 0,  xend that actually uses geom_text is legible. They are in fact uniformly *terrible*. \r\n\r\nThe problem isn't the manual; the problem is with geom_text,  which does not have anything like a reliable means of positioning the labels next to (rather that on) data points. \r\n\r\nEven something that would reliably let you position the text at a fixed number of units above or to the side of the datapoint would be better than what exists now. Obviously something that positioned them in a non-overlapping way would be ideal,  but that's no doubt a lot of work. \r\n\r\nMonkeying with the position tag produces nothing any more legible from what I have been able to produce or find online.\r\n\r\nSurely just making a reliable offset for geom_text should be feasible? This strikes me as so patently obvious that I'm kind of surprised that it has never been done,  especially when even the manual makes it clear that geom_text is woefully unacceptable in its current form. { "_id" : { "$oid" : "52b42983bd354315cf01648a" }, "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/890", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/890/labels{ /name }", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/890/comments", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/890/events", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/890", "id" : 24617108, "number" : 890, "title" : "Add a new \"just touching\" position option for geom_bar", "user" : { "login" : "Robinlovelace", "id" : 1825120, "avatar_url" : "https://gravatar.com/avatar/67b1027cca3877a76a9024425519ddde?d=https%3A%2F%2Fidenticons.github.com%2F007653f22ec9a3fe88216c803aae032f.png&r=x", "gravatar_id" : "67b1027cca3877a76a9024425519ddde", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace", "html_url" : "https://github.com/Robinlovelace", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/followers", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/following{ /other_user }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/subscriptions", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/orgs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/events{ /privacy }", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/Robinlovelace/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2013-12-20T11:26:54Z", "updated_at" : "2013-12-20T11:26:54Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "html_url" : null, "diff_url" : null, "patch_url" : null }, "body" : "geom_bar does not handle variable width bars well. If they are wide they overlap; if they are thin,  large gaps are left between them. This is rarely useful. Instead,  a \"just touching\" option allows for neat 'horizontal' stacking of the bars. This can be done using cumsums (see here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20688376/how-to-make-variable-bar-widths-in-ggplot2-not-overlap-or-gap/20690333?noredirect=1#comment30993310_20690333 ) \r\n\r\nx <- c(\"a\", \"b\", \"c\")\r\nw <- c(1.2,  1.3,  4) # variable widths\r\ny <- c(9,  10,  6) # variable heights\r\n\r\npos <- 0.5 * (cumsum(w) + cumsum(c(0,  w[ -length(w) ])))\r\n\r\nggplot() + \r\ngeom_bar(aes(x = pos,  y = y,  width = w,  fill=x),  stat=\"identity\")\r\n\r\nMy request is that a new position option (1ouching) should be created,  such that the following code would result in the same plot as above:\r\n\r\nggplot() + \r\ngeom_bar(aes(x = x,  y = y,  width = w,  fill=x),  stat=\"identity\",  position = \"touching\")\r\n\r\nin addition,  the function position_touching(gapwidth = 0) could be used to set the width of the gaps in a consistent way. Just ideas,  that I'm actually up for trying to implement if someone gives me an idea of where to start. Sure this would be of use if it ever gets implemented. Thanks!\r\n\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

I'm looking at behavior of different groups of people (called Clusters in this data set) and their preference for the type of browser they use. I want to create a bar graph that shows the percentage of each cluster that is using each type of browser.\r\n\r\nHere is some code to generate a similar dataset (please ignore that the percentages for each cluster will not add up to 1):\r\n\r\nbrowserNames <- c(\"microsoft\", \"mozilla\", \"google\")\r\nclusterNames <- c(\"Cluster 1\", \"Cluster 2\", \"Cluster 3\")\r\npercentages <- runif(n=length(browserNames)*length(clusterNames), min=0, max=1)\r\n\r\nmyData<-as.data.frame(list(browserNames=rep(browserNames, 3), \r\n                           clusterNames=rep(clusterNames, each=3), \r\n                           percentages=percentages))\r\n\r\nHere's the code I've been able to come up with so far to get the graph I desire:\r\n\r\nggplot(myData,  aes(x=browserNames,  y=percentages,  fill=factor(clusterNames))) +\r\n    geom_bar(stat=\"identity\", position=\"dodge\") +\r\n    scale_y_continuous(name=\"Percent Weight\",  labels=percent)\r\n\r\nI want the fill for each cluster to be a gradient fill with high and low values that I determine. In [ `stat_boxplot()` ](https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/blob/c181c8ce5c0b95149b98a861810120f5696e212c/R/stat-boxplot.r#L51),  could the following line be adapted to accept a parameter value from 1 to 9?  \r\n```\r\n } else { \r\n   stats <- as.numeric(quantile(y,  qs))\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\nI don't understand all the internal functions of ggplot2,  so I don't know if there would be downstream problems.  In #108,  it was mentioned that it's not easy to allow the user to specify `fivenum()` instead of `quantile()`.  Hopefully this won't be as difficult,  since it's the same function,  and only an optional parameter changes.\r\n\r\nThe [ `quantile()` ](http://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/stats/html/quantile.html) documentation apparently concedes that its default isn't the recommendation of people who have thought about the differences. I guess they kept it way for backward compatibility.  Notice the authors of the function are Ivan Frohne and Rob J **Hyndman**.\r\n> Further details are provided in **Hyndman** and Fan (1996) who recommended type 8. The default method is type 7,  as used by S and by R < 2.0.0.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/902.patch" }, "body" : "I've added an `offset` argument to `stat_bin()` so that one can change shift the bins left or right without having to specify all the breaks.  Currently,  this only affects things when both `breaks` and `origin` are NULL,  but one could imagine expanding the use case.\r\n\r\nAs is,  it is now simple to choose a width and control the centers/edges of bins without needing to query the data and create breaks manually.   For example,  to get bins centered on integers,  use \r\n\r\n```r\r\nbinwidth = 1,  offset=0.5\r\n```\r\n\r\nI have not added any examples,  but the offset argument is documented in the usage section.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

Here small test case for ggplot2 9.3.1.99 / R 3.0.2,  either \r\nOSX 10.9.1  or RH  6:\r\n\r\n```\r\ndata <- data.frame(x=rnorm(1000), y= rnorm(1000))\r\n\r\n# this works as expected\r\nggplot(data,  aes(x,  y)) + \r\n  stat_bin2d( aes(fill=..count..)) + \r\n  scale_fill_gradient(low=\"green\",  high=\"red\") \r\n\r\n# this one does not - instead of doing an empty plot it stops with\r\n# Error in unit(tic_pos.c,  \"mm\") : 'x' and 'units' must have length > 0\r\nempty.df <- subset(data,  x> 1e9)\r\nggplot(empty.df,  aes(x,  y)) + \r\n  stat_bin2d( aes(fill=..count..)) + \r\n  scale_fill_gradient(low=\"green\",  high=\"red\") \r\n```\r\nI'm using this fragment in a function from inside other expressions to build up more complex plots,  so currently I need to workaround with \r\n```\r\nggplot ( <stuff>) + \r\n  (if (!empty(data)) scale_fill_gradient(low=\"green\",  high=\"red\")  else geom_blank() ) +\r\n   <more ggplot stuff> +  \r\n```\r\nThis works,  but is a bit awkward.\r\n\r\n Cheers,  Dirk\r\n\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/912.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/912.patch" }, "body" : "This is a fix for issue #825.\r\n\r\nIt seems that when a dotplot is created using `geom_dotplot` a couple of parameters (binaxis,  stackdir,  stackgroups,  etc.) are assigned default values. When a dotplot is created using  `qplot(mpg,  data=mtcars,  geom=\"dotplot\")` these params are not defined. The `reparameterise` function of GeomDotplot expect some of these params to be defined thus dotplot does not work with qplot.\r\n\r\nThe easy fix for this for `reparameterise` to check if these params are defined and if not use defaults. I've implemented these checks and have used the same defaults as used in the `geom_dotplot` function. Using this fix \r\n\r\n`qplot(mpg,  data=mtcars,  geom=\"dotplot\")`\r\n\r\ndoes not result in an error and gives the same output as\r\n\r\n`ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x = mpg)) + geom_dotplot()`\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/825", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

0.279258469119668,  0.828579724766314)),  layers = list(\r\n#        <environment>),  scales = <S4 object of class \"Scales\">,  mapping = list(),  \r\n#        theme = list(),  coordinates = list(limits = list(x = NULL,  \r\n#            y = NULL)),  facet = list(shrink = TRUE),  plot_env = <environment>,  \r\n#        labels = list(x = \"x\",  y = \"y\")))\r\n\r\nggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x,  y)) +\r\n  scale_x_continuous(trans=\"log10\",  limits=c(0.001, 1))\r\n# -> works\r\n```\r\n\r\nOf course,  the same happens when supplying `-Inf` with no transformation (but that's less likely to happen)\r\n\r\n```\r\nggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x,  y)) + scale_x_continuous(limits=c(-Inf, 1))\r\n# Error in seq.default(from = best$lmin,  to = best$lmax,  by = best$lstep) : \r\n#   'from' must be of length 1\r\ntraceback()\r\n# 19: stop(\"'from' must be of length 1\")\r\n# 18: seq.default(from = best$lmin,  to = best$lmax,  by = best$lstep)\r\n# 17: seq(from = best$lmin,  to = best$lmax,  by = best$lstep)\r\n# 16: extended(min(x),  max(x),  n,  only.loose = FALSE,  ...)\r\n# 15: scale$trans$breaks(limits)\r\n# 14: scale_breaks.continuous(scale,  range)\r\n# 13: scale_breaks(scale,  range)\r\n# 12: scale_break_info.continuous(scale,  range)\r\n# 11: scale_break_info(scale,  range)\r\n# 10: train_cartesian(scales$x,  coord$limits$x,  \"x\")\r\n# 9: coord_train.cartesian(coord,  list(x = panel$x_scales[ [ ix ] ],  y = panel$y_scales[ [ iy ] ]))\r\n```\r\n\r\nOne used to be able to specify a non-valid limit (NA,  Inf,  ...) and that would me \"No limit on that side,  just use the data\" (I think). This was practical (and would probably solve that bug). In the code,  I see a warning about providing NA to breaks and labels but nothing for limits. And indeed:\r\n\r\n```\r\nggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x,  y)) + scale_x_continuous(limits=c(NA, 1))\r\n# Error in if (zero_range(range)) {  : missing value where TRUE/FALSE needed\r\n\r\nggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x,  y)) + scale_x_continuous(limits=c(NULL, 1))\r\nggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x,  y)) + scale_x_continuous(trans=\"log10\",  limits=c(NULL, 1))\r\n# -> works but no point on the plot anymore\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe bug is also there when the transformation of breaks gives `Inf`\r\n\r\n```\r\nggplot(d) + geom_point(aes(x,  y)) + scale_x_continuous(trans=\"log10\",  breaks=c(0, 0.5,  1))\r\n# Error in seq.default(dots[ [ 1L ] ][ [ 1L ] ],  dots[ [ 2L ] ][ [ 1L ] ],  length = dots[ [ 3L ] ][ [ 1L ] ]) : \r\n#   'from' cannot be NA,  NaN or infinite\r\ntraceback()\r\n# 20: stop(\"'from' cannot be NA,  NaN or infinite\")\r\n# 19: seq.default(dots[ [ 1L ] ][ [ 1L ] ],  dots[ [ 2L ] ][ [ 1L ] ],  length = dots[ [ 3L ] ][ [ 1L ] ])\r\n# 18: (function (...) \r\n#     UseMethod(\"seq\"))(dots[ [ 1L ] ][ [ 1L ] ],  dots[ [ 2L ] ][ [ 1L ] ],  length = dots[ [ 3L ] ][ [ 1L ] ])\r\n# 17: mapply(seq,  b[ -length(b) ],  b[ -1 ],  length = n + 1,  SIMPLIFY = FALSE)\r\n# 16: unlist(mapply(seq,  b[ -length(b) ],  b[ -1 ],  length = n + 1,  SIMPLIFY = FALSE))\r\n# 15: unique(unlist(mapply(seq,  b[ -length(b) ],  b[ -1 ],  length = n + \r\n#         1,  SIMPLIFY = FALSE)))\r\n# 14: scale_breaks_minor.continuous(scale,  b = major,  limits = range)\r\n# 13: scale_breaks_minor(scale,  b = major,  limits = range)\r\n# 12: scale_break_info.continuous(scale,  range)\r\n# 11: scale_break_info(scale,  range)\r\n# 10: train_cartesian(scales$x,  coord$limits$x,  \"x\")\r\n# 9: coord_train.cartesian(coord,  list(x = panel$x_scales[ [ ix ] ],  y = panel$y_scales[ [ iy ] ]))\r\n...\r\n```\r\n\r\nI've looked into it but I cannot figure how to fix it. I am not even sure wether that should be dealt with within `ggplot2` or `scales`.\r\n\r\nIdeally,  getting Inf,  NA or NULL as one of the limit should fall back to computing the limit with the usual algorithm on that side (i.e. min or max + expand factor).", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

As far as I can tell this option still is not easily available.  It seems like a sensible enough plot to make when exploring the data,  and unfortunately people seem very prone to stumbling into a solution that looks sort-kinda right,  but isn't (e.g. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17368223/ggplot2-multi-group-histogram-with-in-group-proportions-rather-than-frequency and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22181132/normalizing-y-axis-in-histograms-in-r-ggplot-to-proportion-by-group).\r\n\r\nI think the result I'm talking about can be achieved by simply changing\r\n```\r\nresults <- data.frame(count = as.numeric(tapply(weight,  bins,  \r\n        sum,  na.rm = TRUE)),  x = x,  width = width)\r\n```\r\nin ggplot2:::bin with...\r\n```\r\ncount <- as.numeric(tapply(weight,  bins,  sum,  na.rm=TRUE))\r\nresults <- data.frame(\r\n   count = count, \r\n   groupsum= sum(count), \r\n   groupprop=sumcount/sum(count)), \r\n   x = x, \r\n   width = width\r\n)\r\n```", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 1, "created_at" : "2014-04-07T00:32:18Z", "updated_at" : "2014-04-08T01:18:15Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/pulls/939", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/939", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/939.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/939.patch" }, "body" : "Thank you for the fantastic ggplots package!\r\n  \r\nThis is a suggested implementation for specifying a file extension in ```ggsave``` to allow device matching (pdf,  png,  jpg,  etc.) for filenames without extension. The suggestion is motivated by the problem of using ggsave in a shinyApp for letting the user download a plot (for example addressed on StackOverflow here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14810409/save-plots-made-in-a-shiny-app). Because the shiny server provides a temporary file without extension,  ggsave can't match to any of the internally defined device functions. I'm not aware of a currently available solution to this problem and although there are several work-arounds,  I like the simplicity of ggsave and wanted to suggest this solution (not sure if it's the best way to do it,  but it's the most elegant I could think of). This would allow use of ```ggsave``` for a shinyApp ```downloadHandler``` like so:\r\n  \r\n  ```coffee\r\n# In ui.R:\r\ndownloadLink('downloadPlot',  'Download')\r\n\r\n# In server.R:\r\noutput$downloadPlot <- downloadHandler(\r\n  filename = \"myplot.pdf\", \r\n  content = function(file) { \r\n    ggsave(file,  plot = qplot(speed,  dist,  data = cars),  ext = \"pdf\")\r\n   }\r\n)\r\n```\r\nI'm relatively new to GitHub and this is my second contribution to someone else's project,  please forgive if I'm missing some specific conventions or etiquette about forking/pull requests.\r\n\r\nSebastian\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

geom_errorbar(limits,  position=dodge,  width=0.25)\r\nError : Mapping a variable to y and also using stat=\"bin\".\r\n  With stat=\"bin\",  it will attempt to set the y value to the count of cases in each group.\r\n  This can result in unexpected behavior and will not be allowed in a future version of ggplot2.\r\n  If you want y to represent counts of cases,  use stat=\"bin\" and don't map a variable to y.\r\n  If you want y to represent values in the data,  use stat=\"identity\".\r\n  See ?geom_bar for examples. (Defunct; last used in version 0.9.2)\r\n```\r\n\r\nThere are a couple more examples like this in the package. a recent commit (possibly 7fdb328e73a3bfa60e6dd294468fa9566ceb6820) changed the way `aes_string()` responds when a variable is set to NULL.  \r\n\r\n```\r\nrm(list=ls(all=TRUE)) called by knitr,  because it's above the first chunk.\r\nrequire(ggplot2)\r\nrequire(datasets)\r\n\r\n#Create a simple dataset for the line\r\ndsLine <- mtcars[  c(\"mpg\",  \"wt\") ]\r\n\r\n#Create a dataset for the ribbon and REMOVE the y variable\r\ndsRibbon <- dsLine\r\ndsRibbon$upper <- dsRibbon$wt + .5\r\ndsRibbon$lower <- dsRibbon$wt - .5\r\ndsRibbon$waylower <- dsRibbon$wt - 10\r\n\r\ndsRibbon$wt <- NULL\r\n\r\n(g <- ggplot(dsLine,  aes_string(x=\"mpg\",  y=\"wt\")) + geom_line())\r\n```\r\nSetting y to NULL works with `aes` (unlike `aes_string` below).\r\n```\r\ng + geom_ribbon(mapping=aes(y=NULL,  ymin=lower,  ymax=upper),  data=dsRibbon,  alpha=.1)\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ image ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1372890/3043493/381e1922-e107-11e3-84d1-fd9c19e089c5.png)\r\n\r\nThis still looks for 'wt',  even though y is set to NULL.\r\n```\r\n#   The error is \"Error in eval(expr,  envir,  enclos) : object 'wt' not found\"\r\ng + geom_ribbon(mapping=aes_string(y=NULL,  ymin=\"lower\",  ymax=\"upper\"),  data=dsRibbon,  alpha=.1)\r\n```\r\nThis looks for `wt`,  even though the the geom_ribbon doesn't need it. (Am I correct that y isn't needed?)\r\n```\r\n#   The error is \"Error in eval(expr,  envir,  enclos) : object 'wt' not found\"\r\ng + geom_ribbon(mapping=aes_string(ymin=\"lower\",  ymax=\"upper\"),  data=dsRibbon,  alpha=.1)\r\n```\r\nThis changes y to some variable that is present in the dataset,  but not used by geom_ribbon. This produces the intended graph.\r\n\r\n```\r\ng + geom_ribbon(mapping=aes_string(y=\"lower\",  ymin=\"lower\",  ymax=\"upper\"),  data=dsRibbon,  alpha=.1)\r\n```\r\n![ image ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1372890/3043546/9bf87ffa-e107-11e3-90b2-67db62a2594c.png)\r\n\r\nThis changes y to some variable that is present in the dataset,  but not used by geom_ribbon. However the low value still affects the y coordinates.\r\n```\r\ng + geom_ribbon(mapping=aes_string(y=\"waylower\",  ymin=\"lower\",  ymax=\"upper\"),  data=dsRibbon,  alpha=.1)\r\n```\r\n![ image ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1372890/3043540/9456e7d2-e107-11e3-805b-8213bef748af.png)\r\n\r\n(Brian Ripley was kind enough to point this out to me this morning that my [ Wats ](https://github.com/wibeasley/Wats) package will break with ggplot2 1.0.0. "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/subscriptions", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/orgs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/events{ /privacy }", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2014-06-01T11:23:57Z", "updated_at" : "2014-06-01T11:23:57Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/pulls/969", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/969", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/969.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/969.patch" }, "body" : "The difference between setting the limits through a coordinate system or via a scale is central to ggplot but the two procedures are not consistent with each other. Compared to scales,  the coord functions lack an expand argument. More importantly,  they do not apply the default expansion and the same plot will look different in function of which method was used to set limits.\r\n\r\nThis pull request implements `xexpand` and `yexpand` arguments for coord functions,  with the same default expansion as for the scales.\r\n\r\nSince setting the limits through coord is symmetric to setting the limits with scales,  it should happen in the same place in the code. Furthermore,  this allows to know if the scale is continuous or discrete thanks to the scale object being passed along. To make this possible,  I changed the coord object to reflect the scale object structure. Coord objects now contains two lists named `x` and `y`,  each containing `expand` and limits. In order to make the difference between passing the whole coord object and passing the x or y component,  I added a dot to `coord`. When a function receives a `.coord`,  we know it is the x or y component of a coord object.\r\n\r\nOne difficulty that I encountered while checking that everything was ok,  is that coord_polar does not have the x and y components. And it needs special treatment for the default expansion,  which depends on theta being equal to \"x\" or \"y\".  My solution was to add x and y objects,  containing theta,  with class set to \"polar\" so that `coord_expand_defaults` dispatches correctly the .coord object to `coord_expand_defaults.polar`.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "53e533cebd3543a370008298" }, "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/974", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/974/labels{ /name }", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/974/comments", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/974/events", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/974", "id" : 35744964, "number" : 974, "title" : "Facet titles", "user" : { "login" : "lionelgit", "id" : 4465050, "avatar_url" : "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4465050?v=2", "gravatar_id" : "4f4eeaab8247b7a4221336902f376a14", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit", "html_url" : "https://github.com/lionelgit", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/followers", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/following{ /other_user }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/subscriptions", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/orgs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/events{ /privacy }", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/lionelgit/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2014-06-15T08:24:17Z", "updated_at" : "2014-06-15T08:24:17Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/pulls/974", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/974", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/974.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/974.patch" }, "body" : "This implements a `switch_strips` argument to `facet_wrap` and `facet_grid`,  which can be set to `x`,  `y` or `both` (the latter only for grids). This allows to display the facet strips near the axes. They then act as axes subtitles. The padding between the switched strips and their corresponding axes can be adjusted through a new theme setting.\r\n\r\nDisplaying the facet titles near the axes especially makes sense when the facet title directly characterize a change in the axis (for example,  a transformation,  a different measure,  etc). This should be typically used in conjunction with a theme without boxes around the strips. I go over this in the updated documentation.\r\n\r\nA grid facetting with strips switched to both axes:\r\n![ facet1 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4465050/3280482/1c1e20c4-f466-11e3-8718-a9dcbd88b551.png)\r\n\r\nA wrap facetting with free scales and strips switched to the x axis:\r\n![ facet2 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4465050/3280481/1c1dcd0e-f466-11e3-9ae3-403ca7b3d9a3.png)\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "53ac64cebd3543adba01d506" }, "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/980", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/980/labels{ /name }", "comments_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/980/comments", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/980/events", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/980", "id" : 36600783, "number" : 980, "title" : "sqrt_trans,  scale limit expansion,  and missing breaks", "user" : { "login" : "BrianDiggs", "id" : 463252, "avatar_url" : "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/463252?", "gravatar_id" : "b03b24d83939c4e11735af5340d90409", "url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs", "html_url" : "https://github.com/BrianDiggs", "followers_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/followers", "following_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/following{ /other_user }", "gists_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/gists{ /gist_id }", "starred_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/starred{ /owner }{ /repo }", "subscriptions_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/subscriptions", "organizations_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/orgs", "repos_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/repos", "events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/events{ /privacy }", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2014-06-26T18:22:03Z", "updated_at" : "2014-06-26T18:22:03Z", "closed_at" : null, "body" : "Prompted by a posting on the mailing list (https://groups.google.com/d/topic/ggplot2/IUje5H0jwm4).\r\n\r\n# Summary\r\n\r\nSpecific problem: Breaks near 0 are not displayed when the square root transformation is applied to a scale.\r\n\r\nGeneral problem: Scale expansion in transformed coordinate space can lead to values which are not meaningfully (or correctly) invertable to data space leading to improperly excluded breaks.\r\n\r\n# Reproducible example:\r\n\r\n```{ r }\r\nlibrary(\"ggplot2\")\r\nlibrary(\"scales\")\r\n\r\nDF <- data.frame(x = seq(0, 1, by=0.1), \r\n                 y = seq(0, 1, by=0.1))\r\n\r\nggplot(DF,  aes(x=x,  y=y)) + \r\n  geom_point() + \r\n  scale_x_sqrt() +\r\n  scale_y_continuous()\r\n```\r\n\r\n# Expected result\r\n\r\nA plot with breaks labeled at 0,  0.25,  0.50,  0.75,  and 1.00\r\n\r\n# Actual results\r\n\r\n![ Actual results ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/463252/3401986/6130d7b2-fd56-11e3-8b1f-8c62e15899fd.png)\r\n\r\nNote that there is no 0 break on the x-axis.\r\n\r\n# Discussion\r\n\r\nThe error occurs because when the limits (in coordinate space) are expanded,  there are negative values which,  when transformed back to data space,  give the incorrect limits from which breaks are determined (or at least limited). Stepping through the effective steps that occur for getting the breaks shows:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nst <- sqrt_trans()\r\n(x<-st$transform(c(0, 1)))\r\n## [ 1 ] 0 1\r\n(x<-expand_range(x,  0.05,  0))\r\n## [ 1 ] -0.05  1.05\r\n(limits<-st$inverse(x))\r\n## [ 1 ] 0.0025 1.1025\r\n(breaks<-st$breaks(limits))\r\n## [ 1 ] 0.00 0.25 0.50 0.75 1.00\r\nst$trans(breaks)\r\n## [ 1 ] 0.0000 0.5000 0.7071 0.8660 1.0000\r\nst$trans(limits)\r\n## [ 1 ] 0.05 1.05\r\ncensor(st$trans(breaks),  st$trans(limits))\r\n## [ 1 ]     NA 0.5000 0.7071 0.8660 1.0000\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe real problem is that the result of the `expand_range` call lies outside the domain of the transformation. How should extra-domain values be treated? \r\n\r\n# Workarounds\r\n\r\n## Don't square negative values\r\n\r\nOne solution to this problem is an alternative transformation,  one that does not invert negative values. A transformation should be one-to-one (within its domain) and `sqrt_trans` is,  but it happily will run the inverse on negative values which can not occur if everything is constrained within the domain. A simple approach is to just map all negative values to 0\r\n\r\n```r\r\nmysqrt_trans <- function() { \r\n  trans_new(\"mysqrt\",  \r\n            transform = base::sqrt, \r\n            inverse = function(x) ifelse(x<0,  0,  x^2), \r\n            domain = c(0,  Inf))\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\n## Squish range before inverting\r\n\r\nIf we assume that all transformations are monotonic (I'm not sure if ggplot2/scales assume transformations are monotonic or just one-to-one; I can not come up with a useful transformation which is not,  though I can create a pathological one.),  then it is reasonable to squish any values outside the range (not domain) of the transformation. Bringing them back to the nearest extreme should be sufficient. Therefore a more general approach for an inverse would be\r\n\r\n```r\r\nmysqrt_trans <- function() { \r\n  domain <- c(0,  Inf)\r\n  transform <- base::sqrt\r\n  range <- transform(domain)\r\n  trans_new(\"mysqrt\",  \r\n            transform = transform, \r\n            inverse = function(x) squish(x,  range=range)^2, \r\n            domain = domain)\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\n## Squish to range whenever values are extended\r\n\r\nThis approach makes it the responsibility of the code which manipulates transformed (coordinate space) values to squish those to the appropriate range if there is any chance that that range is violated. If monotonicity is assumed,  I think any interpolations should be safe,  but any operation which can result in a value more extreme than the existing most extreme values would need to be squished. If this approach is taken,  it would be worth adding an additional component `range` to the `trans` which is just the result of `transform(domain)`.\r\n\r\nThe transformation,  then,  could have its inverse just assume that the data is in the range or it can check that before proceeding (just as now transform may or may not check domain before proceeding). Ideally,  the transformation should throw an error if either `transform` is called with values outside `domain` or `inverse` is called with values outside `range` and this would help pick out places where calling code is not behaving appropriately.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }
{ "_id" : { "$oid" : "53b009b5bd3543acab025bae" }, "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/981", "labels_url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/issues/981/labels{ Here is a minimal example (with a non-linear relationship):\r\n\r\n    library(ggplot2)\r\n    X <- runif(1e4)\r\n    V <- data.frame(x=X,  y=log(X+runif(length(X))))\r\n    p <- ggplot(data = V,  aes(x=x,  y=y))\r\n    p + stat_quantile(quantiles = c(0.05,  0.95),  method = \"rqss\")\r\n\r\nInstead of doing the quantile regression for 0.05,  it may do it for 0.5. This occurs at least half the time (decreasing the number of values reduces the frequency of this problem).\r\n\r\nThis problem disappear when using the rq method.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/pulls/993", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/993", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/993.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/993.patch" }, "body" : "A new theme option,  `panel.ontop`,  places the background objects (panel,  gridlines),  on *top* of the\r\ndata in the plot if set to `TRUE`.  This allows one to place gridlines over the data.  One would typically also include a blank or transparent panel in the theme.\r\n\r\nThis is implemented by changes in facet_panels.* functions,  changing the ordering of layers depending on the value of `theme$panel.ontop`.  `add_theme` was also changed to allow for logical theme elements.\r\n\r\nThis is a simple implementation.  A more advanced one would allow gridlines to be placed on top of data while keeping the panel below data.\r\n\r\nUpdated `theme()` documentation included via roxygen 4.0.1.\r\n\r\nTests passed with the following exception. which I believe is unrelated:\r\n\r\n```\r\nStats : .Error in predLoess(y,  x,  newx,  s,  weights,  pars$robust,  pars$span,  pars$degree,   : \r\n  NA/NaN/Inf in foreign function call (arg 5)\r\nIn addition: Warning message:\r\nIn max(panels$ROW) : no non-missing arguments to max; returning -Inf\r\n```\r\n\r\nFixes #551\r\n\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

containing missing values (position_stack). \r\n    2: In min(x) : no non-missing arguments to min; returning Inf\r\n    3: In max(x) : no non-missing arguments to max; returning -Inf\r\n    4: 0, "created_at" : "2014-10-13T05:35:21Z", "updated_at" : "2014-10-13T05:38:56Z", "closed_at" : null, "body" : "This bug cost me a full day of working.\r\n\r\nSome sample of working code\r\n\r\nabc <- adply(matrix(rnorm(100,  mean = 20,  sd = 5),  ncol = 5),  2,  quantile,  c(0,  .25,  .5,  .75,  1))\r\nabc$X1  <- NULL\r\nabc$X1  <- c(1:5)\r\nabc[ 6,   ]  <- c(10,  18,  20,  25,  1000,  6)\r\n\r\n# working code\r\nb <- ggplot(abc,  aes(group=X1,  x = X1,  ymin = `0%`,  lower = `25%`,  middle = `50%`,  upper = `75%`,  ymax = `100%`))\r\n b + geom_boxplot(stat = \"identity\",  aes(fill=X1)) + coord_trans(y=\"log10\")\r\n\r\nThis all ok. Picture is ok. \r\n![ image ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1291741/4609305/f83d7504-529a-11e4-8e58-2c60ba747d98.png)\r\n\r\n\r\n# broken code\r\nb <- ggplot(abc,  aes(group=X1,  x = X1,  ymin = `0%`,  lower = `25%`,  middle = `50%`,  upper = `75%`,  ymax = `100%`))\r\nd <- b + geom_boxplot(stat = \"identity\") + scale_y_log10()\r\n\r\nggplot makes ranges of y axe as  c(0.8490745,  3.1024250). \r\nmax value from abc is 1000 = 10^3. \r\ny range upper bound = 10^3 + small margin. So it is log scale.\r\nBUT when data is plotted ggplot uses absolute values of abc data not log values.\r\nSo we have wrong picture \r\n![ image ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1291741/4609312/0cc97400-529b-11e4-9691-13d369b2e647.png)\r\n\r\n\r\nProblem like this was discussed here \r\nhttps://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/274\r\nhttp://stackoverflow.com/questions/9502003/ggplot-scale-y-log10-issue\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

Since rasters are often very large (>memory) they should be subsampled for efficient plotting. This is implemented in the raster package for calls to raster::plot but it would be nice to have a fortify method for use with ggplot2. \r\n\r\nThere are three classes RasterLayer,  RasterBrick and RasterStack which can all be subsampled in the same way using a regular grid.The maximal number of pixels to plot can be specified and defaults to 500000.\r\n\r\nFortify returns a data.frame with pixel coordinates and corresponding raster values intended for use with geom_raster.\r\n\r\nWhat do you think?\r\nBenjamin", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

The new geom function works fine with segmentsGrob. segmentsGrob2 itself works fine on it's own. But combined (the new geom calling segmentsGrob2) nothing gets drawn. Examining the gTree of the panel the node that should hold the new grobs are empty (but the node exist).\r\nI'm lost as to where in the evaluation things mess up and would appreciate any pointers. Downright 'it's not possible' answers are also appreciated (might be ggplot2 rely on the grid namespace in a way that makes it impossible to extend it with new grobs)\r\n\r\nMy current code is:\r\n```R\r\ngeom_segment2 <- function(mapping = NULL,  data = NULL,  stat = \"identity\", \r\n                           position = \"identity\",  arrow = NULL,  lineend = \"butt\",  na.rm = FALSE,  startAdjust = NULL,  endAdjust = NULL,  ...) { \r\n    \r\n    GeomSegment2$new(mapping = mapping,  data = data,  stat = stat, \r\n                     position = position,  arrow = arrow,  lineend = lineend,  na.rm = na.rm,  startAdjust = startAdjust,  endAdjust = endAdjust,  ...)\r\n }\r\n\r\nGeomSegment2 <- proto(ggplot2:::Geom,  { \r\n    objname <- \"segment2\"\r\n    \r\n    draw <- function(.,  data,  scales,  coordinates,  arrow = NULL, \r\n                     lineend = \"butt\",  na.rm = FALSE,  startAdjust = startAdjust,  endAdjust = endAdjust,  ...) { \r\n        \r\n        data <- remove_missing(data,  na.rm = na.rm, \r\n                               c(\"x\",  \"y\",  \"xend\",  \"yend\",  \"linetype\",  \"size\",  \"shape\"), \r\n                               name = \"geom_segment\")\r\n        if (empty(data)) return(zeroGrob())\r\n        \r\n        if (is.linear(coordinates)) { \r\n            return(with(coord_transform(coordinates,  data,  scales),  { \r\n                segmentsGrob2(x,  y,  xend,  yend,  default.units=\"native\",  startAdjust=startAdjust,  endAdjust=endAdjust, \r\n                              gp = gpar(col=alpha(colour,  alpha),  fill = alpha(colour,  alpha), \r\n                                        lwd=size * .pt,  lty=linetype,  lineend = lineend), \r\n                                        arrow = arrow)\r\n             }\r\n            ))\r\n         }\r\n        \r\n        data$group <- 1:nrow(data)\r\n        starts <- subset(data,  select = c(-xend,  -yend))\r\n        ends <- rename(subset(data,  select = c(-x,  -y)),  c(\"xend\" = \"x\",  \"yend\" = \"y\"), \r\n                       warn_missing = FALSE)\r\n        \r\n        pieces <- rbind(starts,  ends)\r\n        pieces <- pieces[ order(pieces$group),  ]\r\n        \r\n        GeomPath$draw_groups(pieces,  scales,  coordinates,  arrow = arrow,  ...)\r\n     }\r\n    \r\n    \r\n    default_stat <- function(.) StatIdentity\r\n    required_aes <- c(\"x\",  \"y\",  \"xend\",  \"yend\")\r\n    default_aes <- function(.) aes(colour=\"black\",  size=0.5,  linetype=1,  alpha = NA)\r\n    guide_geom <- function(.) \"path\"\r\n })\r\nsegmentsGrob2 <- function(x0 = unit(0,  \"npc\"),  y0 = unit(0,  \"npc\"),  x1 = unit(1,  \"npc\"),  y1 = unit(1,  \"npc\"),  \r\n                          startAdjust = unit(0,  'npc'),  endAdjust = unit(0,  'npc'),  default.units = \"npc\",  \r\n                          arrow = NULL,  name = NULL,  gp = gpar(),  vp = NULL) { \r\n    if (!is.unit(x0)) \r\n        x0 <- unit(x0,  default.units)\r\n    if (!is.unit(x1)) \r\n        x1 <- unit(x1,  default.units)\r\n    if (!is.unit(y0)) \r\n        y0 <- unit(y0,  default.units)\r\n    if (!is.unit(y1)) \r\n        y1 <- unit(y1,  default.units)\r\n    grid.draw(grob(x0 = x0,  y0 = y0,  x1 = x1,  y1 = y1,  startAdjust=startAdjust,  endAdjust=endAdjust,  \r\n              arrow = arrow,  name=name,  gp=gp,  vp=vp,  cl=\"segments2\"))\r\n }\r\ndrawDetails.segments2 <- function(x,  recording=TRUE) { \r\n    devSize <- dev.size()\r\n    transformation <- matrix(c(devSize[ 1 ],  0,  0,  devSize[ 2 ]),  ncol=2)\r\n    newVec <- cbind(as.numeric(x$x1)-as.numeric(x$x0),  as.numeric(x$y1)-as.numeric(x$y0)) %*% transformation\r\n    segAngle <- atan2(newVec[ , 2 ],  newVec[ ,  1 ])\r\n    xAdjust <- cos(segAngle)\r\n    yAdjust <- sin(segAngle)\r\n    if(!is.null(x$startAdjust)) { \r\n        x$x0 <- x$x0 + unit(as.numeric(x$startAdjust)*xAdjust,  attributes(x$startAdjust)$unit)\r\n        x$y0 <- x$y0 + unit(as.numeric(x$startAdjust)*yAdjust,  attributes(x$startAdjust)$unit)\r\n     }\r\n    if(!is.null(x$endAdjust)) { \r\n        x$x1 <- x$x1 - unit(as.numeric(x$endAdjust)*xAdjust,  attributes(x$endAdjust)$unit)\r\n        x$y1 <- x$y1 - unit(as.numeric(x$endAdjust)*yAdjust,  attributes(x$endAdjust)$unit)\r\n     }\r\n    if(!is.null(x$arrow)) { \r\n        x$x0 <- x$x0 + unit(ifelse(x$arrow$ends %in% c(1, 3),  xAdjust*(x$size * ggplot2:::.pt)/96,  0),  'inch')\r\n        x$y0 <- x$y0 + unit(ifelse(x$arrow$ends %in% c(1, 3),  yAdjust*(x$size * ggplot2:::.pt)/96,  0),  'inch')\r\n        x$x1 <- x$x1 - unit(ifelse(x$arrow$ends %in% c(2, 3),  xAdjust*(x$size * ggplot2:::.pt)/96,  0),  'inch')\r\n        x$y1 <- x$y1 - unit(ifelse(x$arrow$ends %in% c(2, 3),  yAdjust*(x$size * ggplot2:::.pt)/96,  0),  'inch')\r\n     }\r\n    grid.segments(x0 = x$x0,  y0 = x$y0,  x1 = x$x1,  y1 = x$y1,  arrow = x$arrow,  name=x$name,  gp=x$gp,  vp=x$vp)\r\n }\r\n```\r\n\r\nFor what it's worth,  what I'm trying to do is to have a segment where the line stops a fixed length before it reaches its end point,  making it possible to position arrowheads more directly e.g. at the periphery of a circle...", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"\r\nEven though ggplot successfully plots points where the x-axis is a POSIXct,  calling \"geom_vline\" with the x-intercept being set to the same x values gives the error \"Error: Discrete value supplied to continuous scale\".\r\n\r\nIt seems like a bug that the code below labeled \"Does NOT work.\"  would produce this error.\r\n\r\nThis issue is similar but not the quite the same as other issues I have seen in \"hadley / ggplot2\".\r\n\r\nThanks, \r\n\r\n\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\n\r\nxdf <- data.frame(datetime = seq(as.POSIXct('2015-01-01 15:00:00'),  length.out = 5,  by = 'day'), \r\n                  count = 1:5)\r\n### Grab subset of xdf\r\nydf <- xdf %>% filter(count >= 3,  count <= 4)\r\n\r\n#########################################\r\n### Does NOT work.\r\n#########################################\r\nggplot(xdf,  aes(datetime,  count)) +\r\n  geom_point() +\r\n  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = datetime))\r\n# Error: Discrete value supplied to continuous scale\r\n\r\n#########################################\r\n### Does NOT work.\r\n#########################################\r\nggplot(xdf,  aes(datetime,  count)) +\r\n  geom_point() +\r\n  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = datetime),  data = ydf)\r\n# Error: Discrete value supplied to continuous scale\r\n\r\n#########################################\r\n### Works (i.e. plots correctly)\r\n#########################################\r\nggplot(xdf,  aes(datetime,  count)) +\r\n  geom_point() +\r\n  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = as.numeric(datetime)))\r\n### Also Today,  this resulted in incorrect assignments of x axis labels to the data. Code for a (hopefully) reproducible example is below. I was using `fill` and `color` for an explorative analysis of two categorical variables, \r\nand noticed that after adding facet_grid on a third variable,  the assignment of the x axis labels\r\nwas off.\r\n\r\nThe small table (6 x 32) can be downloaded here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/zu4i7xbg0hl64l7/ggplot2.xls?dl=0.\r\nThe data looks like this:\r\n\r\n```\r\nCustomer | UnitA | UnitB | Category | Change | Month | CEO\r\n---------|-------|-------|----------|--------|-------|------\r\nA1\t| 23668\t| 402393\t| high| \t6.491608782\t| January\t| John\r\nA2\t| 4098\t| 83704\t| high\t| 7.798828697\t| March\t| John\r\nA3 | \t19568\t| 320138\t| high\t| 6.246519899\t| January\t| John\r\n...\r\n```\r\n\r\nNow,  this works:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\ndf = read.delim(\"ggplot2.xls\")\r\n## creating the plot based on df as is\r\np = ggplot(df, \r\n       aes(x = Customer,  y = log2(Change), \r\n           fill = CEO,  color = Category)) +\r\n   geom_bar(stat = \"identity\") +\r\n   theme(text = element_text(size = 8), \r\n         axis.text.x = element_text(hjust = 1,  vjust = 1,  angle = 45)) +\r\n   scale_color_manual(values = c(\"firebrick3\",  \"darkblue\")) +\r\n   scale_fill_manual(values = c(\"grey70\",  \"grey80\"))\r\n   \r\n## no difference in \"Category\" between simple barplot, \r\np\r\n## and after adding facets\r\np + facet_grid(. ~ Month,  scales = \"free\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nSee images 1 and 2.\r\n\r\n![ image1 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1090101/6322840/6cc78892-baec-11e4-8dd2-fd1d122467dd.png)\r\n![ image2 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1090101/6322842/6ccc6d94-baec-11e4-9486-004629555cbe.png)\r\n\r\nRedrawing the plot using data.frame row names to label the x axis,  everything is fine\r\nwithout adding facets (image3.png),  but \r\n\r\n```r\r\nrownames(df) = df$Customer\r\n\r\np = ggplot(df, \r\n       aes(x = rownames(df),  y = log2(Change), \r\n           fill = CEO,  color = Category)) +\r\n   geom_bar(stat = \"identity\") +\r\n   theme(text = element_text(size = 8), \r\n         axis.text.x = element_text(hjust = 1,  vjust = 1,  angle = 45)) +\r\n   scale_color_manual(values = c(\"firebrick3\",  \"darkblue\")) +\r\n   scale_fill_manual(values = c(\"grey70\",  \"grey80\"))\r\n\r\n## simple barplot correct,  see image3.png\r\np\r\n## now Customer and Category do not match! (image4.png)\r\np + facet_grid(. ~ Month,  scales = \"free\")\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n![ image3 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1090101/6322841/6ccbedba-baec-11e4-8eef-c3a4cd2af53b.png)\r\n![ image4 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1090101/6322843/6cccd00e-baec-11e4-91a6-d4e91b433a09.png)\r\n\r\nThanks!\r\n\r\n```r\r\nR> sessionInfo()\r\nR version 3.1.2 (2014-10-31)\r\nPlatform: x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0 (64-bit)\r\n\r\nlocale:\r\n[ 1 ] en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/C/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8\r\n\r\nattached base packages:\r\n[ 1 ] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n\r\nother attached packages:\r\n[ 1 ] ggplot2_1.0.0  colorout_1.0-3 setwidth_1.0-3\r\n\r\nloaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n [ 1 ] colorspace_1.2-4 digest_0.6.4     grid_3.1.2       gtable_0.1.2    \r\n [ 5 ] labeling_0.3     MASS_7.3-35      munsell_0.4.2    plyr_1.8.1      \r\n [ 9 ] proto_0.3-10     Rcpp_0.11.3      reshape2_1.4     scales_0.2.4    \r\n[ 13 ] stringr_0.6.2   \r\nR> \r\n```", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

Close\r\ng <- g + scale_colour_manual(name=\"\",  values=c(Down=DC,  Flat=FC,  Up=UC)) # set the colour\r\ng <- g + theme_ohlc\r\ng <- g + geom_line(aes(x=Timeline,  y=Trail),  colour=\"darkred\",  size=1.3) # Trailing Stop\r\ng <- g + geom_line(aes(x=Timeline,  y=Profit.Taker),  colour=\"green\",  size=1.3) # Profit Taker\r\n# . . .\r\ng <- g + scale_x_continuous(breaks=which(Chart$Timeline %% axis.x.interval == 0))\r\ng <- g + theme(axis.ticks.x = element_blank(),  axis.text.x = element_blank())\r\ng <- g + theme(plot.margin  = unit(c(1,  5,  -22,  15),  units = \"points\"))\r\ny.top <- ggplot_build(g)$panel$ranges[ [ 1 ] ]$y.range[ 2 ] # But I am stuck on some (known from what I have searched) issues of stat_contour. \r\n\r\n1) When I set geom=\"polygon\" the levels that are not fully closed are not filled correctly.\r\n2) Higher levels cover/hide the lower levels.\r\n\r\nStraight to a simple example to show you what I mean:\r\n### Creating the data\r\n>library(ggplot2)\r\nx = seq(-1,  1,  length.out = 100)\r\ny = x\r\nR = expand.grid(x,  y)\r\ndim(R)\r\nnames(R) = c(\"x\",  \"y\")\r\nR$z = R$x^2 + R$y^2\r\nhead(R)\r\n\r\n### Ploting contour\r\n>ggplot(R,  aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = z)) + stat_contour()\r\n![ stat_contour1 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8446323/6605024/6ad40550-c835-11e4-9528-9361885931e0.png)\r\n\r\n\r\n### Ploting filled contour by setting geom=\"polygon\"\r\n>ggplot(R,  aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = z)) + stat_contour(geom=\"polygon\")\r\n![ stat_contour2 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8446323/6605028/72b6195c-c835-11e4-8c19-c0faf60e9553.png)\r\n\r\n\r\n### In order to see what is filled correctly and what is not\r\n>ggplot(R,  aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = z,  fill=..level..)) +\r\n  stat_contour(geom=\"polygon\") + \r\n  stat_contour() + \r\n  scale_fill_gradient(low = \"blue\",  high = \"red\") +\r\n  coord_map(xlim=c(-1, 1), ylim=c(-1, 1))\r\n![ stat_contour3 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8446323/6605033/77587982-c835-11e4-9cde-aa6f3b24065c.png)\r\n\r\n\r\n### And if we reverse the values of R$z we can display the inner/hidden levels (multiply *-1)\r\n>ggplot(R*-1,  aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = z,  fill=..level..)) +\r\n  stat_contour(geom=\"polygon\") + \r\n  stat_contour() + \r\n  scale_fill_gradient(low = \"blue\",  high = \"red\") +\r\n  coord_map(xlim=c(-1, 1), ylim=c(-1, 1))\r\n![ stat_contour4 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8446323/6605037/7f0b83cc-c835-11e4-8c41-ef94b5d90a92.png)\r\n\r\n\r\n### The first problem is somehow fixed (not completely) by expanding my grid with the same values that has in each side. Something like this:\r\n>R_fill <- subset(R,  x==1 | x==-1 | y==1 | y==-1)\r\nR_fill[ R_fill$x==1,  ]$x=5\r\nR_fill[ R_fill$x==-1,  ]$x=-5\r\nR_fill[ R_fill$y==1,  ]$y=5\r\nR_fill[ R_fill$y==-1,  ]$y=-5\r\nR_fill <- rbind(R_fill, R)\r\nggplot(R_fill*-1,  aes(x = x,  y = y,  z = z,  fill=..level..)) +\r\n  stat_contour(geom=\"polygon\") + \r\n  stat_contour() + \r\n  scale_fill_gradient(low = \"blue\",  high = \"red\") +\r\n  coord_map(xlim=c(-1, 1), ylim=c(-1, 1))\r\n![ stat_contour5 ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8446323/6605039/84390388-c835-11e4-8267-a9047de12f63.png)\r\n\r\n\r\nTo sum up,  (1) every level that is higher than 1 is not filled correctly since the level line is not closed on the edges. So whenever the level is not closed,  ggplot is forcing a closure by connecting the two edges of the semi-circles. Maybe the only way to correct the above problem is to handle and plot the levels in stat_contour as polygons with certain coordination. Can I somehow obtain the exact point position that belong to each contour line? If I could then I would be able to plot them as polygons and set a certain box around the region I want to plot and \"close\" the \"un-closed\" levels in order to be filled correctly.\r\n\r\nAnd (2) since ggplot (to my understanding) is plotting lower to higher levels,  the lower levels are obscured. I have no idea how this could be fixed,  since some datasets contain regions of lower values around higher levels.\r\n\r\nI don't know how hard is to tackle and correct these problems since I have no experience on the ggplot code. It would be really useful if stat_contour acted as filled.contour,  since ggplot2 has some many possibilities. So I would like to hear your thoughts and your suggestions.\r\n\r\nThank you in advance, \r\nThanos", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

I view it as along the same lines as `stat_ecdf` but for censored data. Before submitting a pull request I wanted to ask if this would be suitable for inclusion in ggplot2,  or if it would be better as a standalone package?\r\n\r\nHere's an example code and plot: \r\n\r\n```r\r\ndf <- survival::lung\r\nggplot(df,  aes(x = time,  status = status,  color = factor(sex))) + geom_km()\r\n```\r\n\r\n![ image ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5464185/6966565/17a8f7ce-d928-11e4-9b02-1a517c532614.png)\r\n\r\n ", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

I've tried to use position=\"dodge\" but in case of my data it's very hard to see anything.\r\n\r\nThen I came across this SO thread: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3541713/how-to-plot-two-histograms-together-in-r (the first couple of plots are density but the rest are actual histograms) and all solutions there are based on using transparency. It occurred to me that a more universal way to do it would be to use solid bars but for each bin,  plot the bars in the order from highest to lowest so that all of them are visible (hope this makes sense). Admittedly it is a weird plot specification but i think it is not one that is uncommon if a plot is build gradually,  I think that some kind of warning or error would be in place.\r\n\r\nWrong plot:\r\n![ rplot ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1662852/7228133/7b7284b4-e756-11e4-9c94-12a94e5f96c0.png)\r\nRight plot:\r\n![ rplot01 3))\r\nd<-do.call('rbind', list(d)[ rep(1, 60) ])\r\n\r\nd$dd<-1\r\nd$ee<-as.numeric(d$a)*8-2\r\nd$t<-2\r\n#all produce the wrong plot\r\nqplot(d$ee-d$dd,  d$t, data=d,  geom='point')+facet_grid(a~b)\r\nqplot(d$ee-d$dd,  t, data=d,  geom='point')+facet_grid(a~b)\r\nqplot(d$ee-d$dd,  t, data=d)+facet_grid(a~b)# wrong plot shown\r\n\r\n# right plot\r\nqplot(ee-dd,  d$t, data=d,  geom='point')+facet_grid(a~b)\r\nqplot(ee-dd,  t, data=d,  geom='point')+facet_grid(a~b)\r\nqplot(ee-dd,  t, data=d)+facet_grid(a~b)# right plot shown\r\n\r\n\r\nd$diff<-d$ee-d$dd\r\nqplot(diff,  d$t, data=d,  geom='point')+facet_grid(a~b)\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\nMy system:\r\n```R\r\n> sessionInfo()\r\nR version 3.2.0 (2015-04-16)\r\nPlatform: 0, "created_at" : "2015-04-20T15:41:25Z", "updated_at" : "2015-04-20T15:41:25Z", "closed_at" : null, "body" : "The documentation of `print.default` states that \r\n\r\n     'print' prints its argument and returns it _invisibly_ (via\r\n     'invisible(x)').\r\n\r\nHence I expected the following to work:\r\n\r\n    plot_obj <- ggplot(data = data.frame(x = 1:10,  y = 1:10),  aes(x = x,  y = y)) + geom_point()\r\n    plot_obj2 <- print(plot_obj)\r\n    print(plot_obj2 + ggtitle(\"testplot\"))\r\n\r\n... but it doesn't (`Error in plot_obj2 + ggtitle(\"testplot\") : non-numeric argument to binary operator`),  since `plot_obj2` is of class `list` and not `ggplot` (as is `plot_obj`).\r\n\r\nA quick look at [ plot-render.r ](https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/blob/4bb9270ef4d5d5062353438fd99d17b6f6de98a2/R/plot-render.r#L179-L195) confirms that `print.ggplot(x)` does not return `x` but rather `ggplot_build(x)` (invisibly).\r\n\r\nSo to summarise, \r\n- the behavior of `print.ggplot` is not in tune with the documentation of `print.default` and\r\n- it is not documented.\r\n\r\nA little bit of context on why I wanted to do this: I have various custom functions that construct ggplot objects and print them. I found it very convenient to just have `print(obj)` as the final statement in my function,  believing that this would also invisibly return the object,  s.t. I could further modify it outside of the function if necessary. Now I have to do `print(obj); invisible(obj)`.\r\n\r\nIs there a reason for this choice of implementation? If yes,  I'd think it should at least be documented.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/ogdenkev/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "locked" : false, "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2015-04-29T14:13:09Z", "updated_at" : "2015-04-29T14:13:09Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/pulls/1092", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1092", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1092.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1092.patch" }, "body" : "This commit adds a new geom,  `geom_schematic()` which follows John Tukey's recommendation for balanced schematic plots (see Tukey J. W. (1990) Data-Based Graphics: Visual Display in the Decades to Come. Statistical Science 5(3),  327-339.) This also more closely follows what `bwplot()` does in the `lattice` package and what William Cleveland uses in his book Visualizing Data.\r\n\r\nThe `geom_schematic()` function started from the `geom_boxplot()` function,  and added lines at the upper and lower ends of the whiskers,  used a point for the median instead of a line. It also added the aesthetics `whiskers.linetype`,  `middle.size`,  and `middle.colour` with the default values of `dashed`,  `4`,  and `NULL`,  respectively. The default for `middle.colour` is to use the `colour` aesthetic,  but with the option of directly specifying it in the call to `geom_schematic()`. The option for notching was removed,  because I didn't think notching would work well with the median as a point.\r\n\r\n![ rplot ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9858547/7392808/2f81e8c0-ee58-11e4-803c-0051fec83741.png)\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

The workaround to explicitly set visual limits with coord_cartesian() works everywhere,  except when using facet_grid(scales = \"free_y\").. so after giving it some thought,  IMHO stat_smooth() should always be ignored when determining the data limits. When using geom_boxplot,  a boxplot is done,  irrespective of the number of data points that are available. This is especially a problem when doing boxplots across various groups (e.g. timepoints) where not always the same number of samples is available. In plotting,  all the boxplots look equivalent,  although it can easily be the case that some are only based on 2-3 points (or even 1).\r\n\r\nTherefore I have the following feature request: Add a parameter to geom_boxplot that requires a minimum number of points for the boxplot to be done. By default it can be set to 0 not to change current behavior. then\r\n1. If minimum number of points reached - do the boxplot as usual\r\n2. If minimum number of points not reached - plot the available data as points instead (with color being equal to the fill color of the boxplot).\r\n\r\nThanks!", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"https://api.github.com/users/evolvedmicrobe/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "locked" : false, "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 1, "created_at" : "2015-05-05T06:17:46Z", "updated_at" : "2015-05-05T06:24:51Z", "closed_at" : null, "pull_request" : { "url" : "https://api.github.com/repos/hadley/ggplot2/pulls/1096", "html_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1096", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1096.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1096.patch" }, "body" : "This commit allows geom_dotplot to display color attributes properly\r\nwhen dots are binned.  Prior to this,  if one ran a command such as:\r\n\r\n    ggplot(mtcars,  aes(x=factor(cyl),  y =mpg,  fill=factor(carb),  group=factor(cyl))) + geom_dotplot(binaxis=\"y\",  stackdir=\"center\")\r\n\r\nThe dots would be positioned on top of each other,  because a \"double\r\ngrouping\" was performed where both the fill and the x axis were used to\r\ndivide groups.  This change keeps the groups appropriately separated\r\nwhen the x/y positions are being determined,  but still applies separate\r\ncoloring to each.\r\n\r\nIt does this by changing where the fill color is added to the data used\r\nwhen plotting.  Previously,  the data was condensed into bins and a\r\ndataframe where each row represented several dots to be plotted during\r\nthe calculate groups step. This condendsed data was then re-expanded\r\nwith a constant fill color added for each binned group inside the\r\nreparameterise method.  This commit re-expands the data into one line\r\nper dot in the original calculate method,  where the appropriate fill\r\n(or other aes) is still available and can be added back in.\r\n\r\nI verified that all the original examples for geom_dotplot still behave\r\nas expected,  and all tests currently pass.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

"events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/events{ /privacy }", "received_events_url" : "https://api.github.com/users/BrianDiggs/received_events", "type" : "User", "site_admin" : false }, "labels" : [  ], "state" : "open", "locked" : false, "assignee" : null, "milestone" : null, "comments" : 0, "created_at" : "2015-05-12T03:44:00Z", "updated_at" : "2015-05-12T03:44:00Z", "closed_at" : null, "body" : "# Summary\r\n\r\nThe algorithms for drawing the lines around bars in `geom_bar` assume that the color is completely opaque and can lead to different colors due to overplotting when semi-transparent.\r\n\r\n# Example\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(\"ggplot2\")\r\nlibrary(\"scales\")\r\nggplot(mtcars[ 1:8,  ],  aes(x = factor(carb),  y = disp)) +\r\ngeom_bar(stat = \"identity\",  lwd = 7,  colour = alpha(\"white\",  0.5)) +\r\ntheme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = \"lightblue\"))\r\n```\r\n\r\n![  ](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/463252/7579755/bc780682-f81d-11e4-92b2-ecf9bde65461.png)\r\n\r\nThe borders are 50% transparent white and absurdly large to make the effects more obvious. The borders between the stacked bars are not all the same color.\r\n\r\n# Discussion\r\n\r\nFixing this completely would be very hard,  especially the double plotting that occurs at the corners. I submit this bug more to mark it as a known issue than to get (or submit) a fix. What I might suggest is a comment in the details section of `geom_bar` such as\r\n\r\n> Borders around bars (defined by the `colour` aesthetic) are drawn assuming a completely opaque color. A semi-transparent color can be used,  but the effects will not be as expected.\r\n", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

To show this in an example,  say I'm plotting 5 straight lines,  and then I want to omit 2 of them:\r\n\r\n    library(ggplot2)\r\n    library(dplyr)\r\n    \r\n    # Sample data: lines\r\n    df <- data.frame(\r\n        x = rep(1:20,  each = 5), \r\n        grouping = factor(rep(1:5,  20))\r\n        )\r\n    df <- within(df,  y <- x * as.numeric(grouping))\r\n    \r\n    # Plot the raw data\r\n    (p1 <- qplot(data = df,  x = x,  y = y,  color = grouping,  geom = \"line\"))\r\n    \r\n    # Subset out 2 of the 5 lines.  This works:\r\n    p1 %+% filter(df,  grouping != 3,  grouping != 4) +\r\n      scale_color_brewer(type = \"div\") %+%\r\n    \r\n    # But this doesn't.  Seems like this should throw an error,  at minimum\r\n    p1 + scale_color_brewer(type = \"div\") %+%\r\n      filter(df,  grouping != 3,  grouping != 4)\r\n\r\nIf this isn't a bug,  it does seem like there should at least be a warning when the user puts in a `%+%` command that ggplot ignores,  so that way I know which data the plot is using in cases where it might not be obvious.\r\n\r\nThanks!  Please let me know if I can help in any other way.", "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

As I was still learning there was some sheer amount of trial and error and I often needed to interrupt a call. Working with RStudio,  it just hang for a couple of seconds and prompt me to terminate the R Session,  which I almost always did. When I didn't,  it just kept going and I grew impatient.\r\n\r\nThis is a minimal example:\r\n\r\n```R\r\nlibrary(ggplot2)\r\nd=data.frame(a=1:10000000, b=runif(10000000))\r\nggplot(data=d)+aes(x=factor(1), y=b)+geom_boxplot()\r\n```\r\n\r\nI suspect that the call that performs the statistical computing or the grid arrangement is never interrupted. It blocks the process and,  when it's finished (if so),  only the rendering is actually aborted.\r\n\r\nMy sessionInfo() for reproducibilty :\r\n\r\n```\r\nR version 3.1.3 (2015-03-09)\r\nPlatform: "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1126", "diff_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1126.diff", "patch_url" : "https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/pull/1126.patch" }, "body" : "With this change,  you can specify one set of breaks to `stat_bin2d` without setting the other.  This is particularly useful when binning by date in one dimension,  and using a transformed scale in the other dimension.  This way,  you don't have to figure out how to reconstruct the default breaks for the transformed scale.  For example:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nbreaks <- list( x = sort(unique(movies$year)) - 0.5,  y = NA )\r\ng <- ggplot(movies) + aes(x = year,  y = length)\r\ng + stat_bin2d(breaks=breaks) + scale_y_log10()\r\n```", "closed_by" : null, "repo" : "ggplot2", "owner" : "hadley" }

are only two values in the series and scale=count used.\r\n\r\n    library(ggplot2)\r\n    d1 <- data.frame(x=c(\"a\", \"a\", \"a\", \"b\", \"b\", \"b\"), y=c(1, 2, 2, 1, 2, 1)) # Two series of three time (in the call to `Layer$new()`),  so that if any external packages inherit from,  say,  `Geom`,  they'll inherit from the current version of ggplot2,  not whatever version they were built against.\r\n\r\n@hadley,  currently the `geom_text2` function doesn't separate the `geom_params` from other `params`,  because some of the `geom_params` include properties like `label`,  `size`,  etc.
